For behold, it was the poorest spot in all the land of thy vineyard.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357340" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>And the Lord of the vineyard said unto him: Counsel me not; I knew that it was a poor spot of ground; wherefore, I said unto thee, I have nourished it this long time, and thou beholdest that it hath brought forth much fruit.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357341" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>And it came to pass that the Lord of the vineyard said unto his servant: Look hither; behold I have planted another branch of the tree also; and thou knowest that this spot of ground was poorer than the first. But, behold the tree. I have nourished it this long time, and it hath brought forth much fruit; therefore, gather it, and lay it up against the season, that I may preserve it unto mine own self.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357342" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>And it came to pass that the Lord of the vineyard said again unto his servant: Look hither, and behold another <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>branch</span> also, which I have planted; behold that I have nourished it also, and it hath brought forth fruit.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357343" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>And he said unto the servant: Look hither and behold the last. Behold, this have I planted in a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>good</span> spot of ground; and I have <span class="page-break" data-page="128"></span>nourished it this long time, and only a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>part</span> of the tree hath brought forth tame fruit, and the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>other</span> part of the tree hath brought forth wild fruit; behold, I have nourished this tree like unto the others.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357344" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>And it came to pass that the Lord of the vineyard said unto the servant: Pluck off the branches that have not brought forth good <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>fruit</span>, and cast them into the fire.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357345" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>But behold, the servant said unto him: Let us prune it, and dig about it, and nourish it a little <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>longer</span>, that perhaps it may bring forth good fruit unto thee, that thou canst lay it up against the season.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357346" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>And it came to pass that the Lord of the vineyard and the servant of the Lord of the vineyard did nourish all the fruit of the vineyard.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357347" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>And it came to pass that a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note29a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>long</span> time had passed away, and the Lord of the vineyard said unto his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note29b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>servant</span>: Come, let us go down into the vineyard, that we may labor again in the vineyard. For behold, the time draweth near, and the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note29c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>end</span> soon cometh; wherefore, I must lay up fruit against the season, unto mine own self.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357348" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>And it came to pass that the Lord of the vineyard and the servant went down into the vineyard; and they came to the tree whose natural branches had been broken off, and the wild branches had been grafted in; and behold all <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note30a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>sorts</span> of fruit did cumber the tree.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357349" id="p31"><span class="verse-number">31 </span>And it came to pass that the Lord of the vineyard did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note31a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>taste</span> of the fruit, every sort according to its number. And the Lord of the vineyard said: Behold, this long time have we nourished this tree, and I have laid up unto myself against the season much fruit.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357350" id="p32"><span class="verse-number">32 </span>But behold, this time it hath brought forth much <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note32a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>fruit</span>, and there is <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note32b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>none</span> of it which is good. And behold, there are all kinds of bad fruit; and it profiteth me nothing, notwithstanding all our labor; and now it grieveth me that I should lose this tree.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357351" id="p33"><span class="verse-number">33 </span>And the Lord of the vineyard said unto the servant: What shall we do unto the tree, that I may preserve again good fruit thereof unto mine own self?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357352" id="p34"><span class="verse-number">34 </span>And the servant said unto his master: Behold, because thou didst graft in the branches of the wild olive tree they have nourished the roots, that they are alive and they have not perished; wherefore thou beholdest that they are yet good.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357353" id="p35"><span class="verse-number">35 </span>And it came to pass that the Lord of the vineyard said unto his servant: The tree profiteth me nothing, and the roots thereof profit me nothing so long as it shall bring forth evil fruit.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357354" id="p36"><span class="verse-number">36 </span>Nevertheless, I know that the roots are good, and for mine own purpose I have preserved them; and because of their much strength they have hitherto brought forth, from the wild branches, good fruit.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357355" id="p37"><span class="verse-number">37 </span>But behold, the wild branches have grown and have <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note37a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>overrun</span> the roots thereof; and because that the wild branches have overcome the roots thereof it hath brought forth much evil fruit; and because that it hath brought forth so much evil fruit thou beholdest that it beginneth to perish; and it will soon become ripened, that it may be cast into the fire, except we should do something for it to preserve it.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357356" id="p38"><span class="verse-number">38 </span>And it came to pass that the Lord of the vineyard said unto his servant: Let us go down into the nethermost parts of the vineyard, and behold if the natural branches have also brought forth evil fruit.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357357" id="p39"><span class="verse-number">39 </span>And it came to pass that they <span class="page-break" data-page="129"></span>went down into the nethermost parts of the vineyard. And it came to pass that they beheld that the fruit of the natural branches had become corrupt also; yea, the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note39a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>first</span> and the second and also the last; and they had all become corrupt.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357358" id="p40"><span class="verse-number">40 </span>And the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note40a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>wild</span> fruit of the last had overcome that part of the tree which brought forth good fruit, even that the branch had withered away and died.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357359" id="p41"><span class="verse-number">41 </span>And it came to pass that the Lord of the vineyard wept, and said unto the servant: <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note41a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>What</span> could I have done more for my vineyard?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357360" id="p42"><span class="verse-number">42 </span>Behold, I knew that all the fruit of the vineyard, save it were these, had become <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note42a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>corrupted</span>. And now these which have once brought forth good fruit have also become corrupted; and now all the trees of my vineyard are good for nothing save it be to be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note42b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>hewn</span> down and cast into the fire.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357361" id="p43"><span class="verse-number">43 </span>And behold this last, whose branch hath withered away, I did plant in a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note43a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>good</span> spot of ground; yea, even that which was choice unto me above all other parts of the land of my vineyard.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357362" id="p44"><span class="verse-number">44 </span>And thou beheldest that I also cut down that which <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note44a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>cumbered</span> this spot of ground, that I might plant this tree in the stead thereof.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357363" id="p45"><span class="verse-number">45 </span>And thou beheldest that a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note45a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>part</span> thereof brought forth good fruit, and a part thereof brought forth wild fruit; and because I plucked not the branches thereof and cast them into the fire, behold, they have overcome the good branch that it hath withered away.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357364" id="p46"><span class="verse-number">46 </span>And now, behold, notwithstanding all the care which we have taken of my vineyard, the trees thereof have become corrupted, that they bring forth no good <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note46a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>fruit</span>; and these I had hoped to preserve, to have laid up fruit thereof against the season, unto mine own self. But, behold, they have become like unto the wild olive tree, and they are of no worth but to be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note46b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>hewn</span> down and cast into the fire; and it grieveth me that I should lose them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357365" id="p47"><span class="verse-number">47 </span>But <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note47a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>what</span> could I have done more in my vineyard? Have I slackened mine hand, that I have not nourished it? Nay, I have nourished it, and I have digged about it, and I have pruned it, and I have dunged it; and I have <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note47b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>stretched</span> forth mine <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note47c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>hand</span> almost all the day long, and the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note47d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>end</span> draweth nigh. And it grieveth me that I should hew down all the trees of my vineyard, and cast them into the fire that they should be burned. Who is it that has corrupted my vineyard?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357366" id="p48"><span class="verse-number">48 </span>And it came to pass that the servant said unto his master: Is it not the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note48a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>loftiness</span> of thy vineyard—have not the branches thereof overcome the roots which are good? And because the branches have overcome the roots thereof, behold they grew faster than the strength of the roots, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note48b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>taking</span> strength unto themselves. Behold, I say, is not this the cause that the trees of thy vineyard have become corrupted?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357367" id="p49"><span class="verse-number">49 </span>And it came to pass that the Lord of the vineyard said unto the servant: Let us go to and hew down the trees of the vineyard and cast them into the fire, that they shall not cumber the ground of my vineyard, for I have done all. What could I have done more for my vineyard?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357368" id="p50"><span class="verse-number">50 </span>But, behold, the servant said unto the Lord of the vineyard: Spare it a little <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note50a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>longer</span>.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="130"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357369" id="p51"><span class="verse-number">51 </span>And the Lord said: Yea, I will spare it a little longer, for it grieveth me that I should lose the trees of my vineyard.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357370" id="p52"><span class="verse-number">52 </span>Wherefore, let us take of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note52a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>branches</span> of these which I have planted in the nethermost parts of my vineyard, and let us graft them into the tree from whence they came; and let us pluck from the tree those branches whose fruit is most bitter, and graft in the natural branches of the tree in the stead thereof.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357371" id="p53"><span class="verse-number">53 </span>And this will I do that the tree may not perish, that, perhaps, I may preserve unto myself the roots thereof for mine <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note53a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>own</span> purpose.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357372" id="p54"><span class="verse-number">54 </span>And, behold, the roots of the natural branches of the tree which I planted whithersoever I would are yet alive; wherefore, that I may preserve them also for mine own purpose, I will take of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note54a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>branches</span> of this tree, and I will <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note54b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>graft</span> them in unto them. Yea, I will graft in unto them the branches of their mother tree, that I may preserve the roots also unto mine own self, that when they shall be sufficiently strong perhaps they may bring forth good fruit unto me, and I may yet have glory in the fruit of my vineyard.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357373" id="p55"><span class="verse-number">55 </span>And it came to pass that they took from the natural tree which had become wild, and grafted in unto the natural trees, which also had become wild.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357374" id="p56"><span class="verse-number">56 </span>And they also took of the natural trees which had become wild, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note56a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>grafted</span> into their mother tree.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357375" id="p57"><span class="verse-number">57 </span>And the Lord of the vineyard said unto the servant: Pluck not the wild branches from the trees, save it be those which are most bitter; and in them ye shall graft according to that which I have said.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357376" id="p58"><span class="verse-number">58 </span>And we will nourish again the trees of the vineyard, and we will trim up the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note58a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>branches</span> thereof; and we will pluck from the trees those branches which are ripened, that must perish, and cast them into the fire.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357377" id="p59"><span class="verse-number">59 </span>And this I do that, perhaps, the roots thereof may take strength because of their goodness; and because of the change of the branches, that the good may <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note59a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>overcome</span> the evil.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357378" id="p60"><span class="verse-number">60 </span>And because that I have preserved the natural branches and the roots thereof, and that I have grafted in the natural branches again into their mother tree, and have preserved the roots of their mother tree, that, perhaps, the trees of my vineyard may bring forth again good <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note60a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>fruit</span>; and that I may have joy again in the fruit of my vineyard, and, perhaps, that I may rejoice exceedingly that I have preserved the roots and the branches of the first fruit—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357379" id="p61"><span class="verse-number">61 </span>Wherefore, go to, and call <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note61a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>servants</span>, that we may <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note61b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>labor</span> diligently with our might in the vineyard, that we may <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note61c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>prepare</span> the way, that I may bring forth again the natural fruit, which natural fruit is good and the most precious above all other fruit.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357380" id="p62"><span class="verse-number">62 </span>Wherefore, let us go to and labor with our might this last time, for behold the end draweth nigh, and this is for the last time that I shall <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note62a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>prune</span> my vineyard.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357381" id="p63"><span class="verse-number">63 </span>Graft in the branches; begin at the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note63a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>last</span> that they may be first, and that the first may be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note63b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>last</span>, and dig about the trees, both old and young, the first and the last; and the last and the first, that all may be nourished once again for the last time.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357382" id="p64"><span class="verse-number">64 </span>Wherefore, dig about them, <span class="page-break" data-page="131"></span>and prune them, and dung them once more, for the last time, for the end draweth nigh. And if it be so that these last grafts shall grow, and bring forth the natural fruit, then shall ye prepare the way for them, that they may grow.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357383" id="p65"><span class="verse-number">65 </span>And as they begin to grow ye shall <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note65a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>clear</span> away the branches which bring forth bitter fruit, according to the strength of the good and the size thereof; and ye shall not clear away the bad thereof all at once, lest the roots thereof should be too strong for the graft, and the graft thereof shall perish, and I lose the trees of my vineyard.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357384" id="p66"><span class="verse-number">66 </span>For it grieveth me that I should lose the trees of my vineyard; wherefore ye shall clear away the bad according as the good shall grow, that the root and the top may be equal in strength, until the good shall overcome the bad, and the bad be hewn down and cast into the fire, that they cumber not the ground of my vineyard; and thus will I sweep away the bad out of my vineyard.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357385" id="p67"><span class="verse-number">67 </span>And the branches of the natural tree will I graft in again into the natural tree;</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357386" id="p68"><span class="verse-number">68 </span>And the branches of the natural tree will I graft into the natural branches of the tree; and thus will I bring them together again, that they shall bring forth the natural <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note68a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>fruit</span>, and they shall be one.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357387" id="p69"><span class="verse-number">69 </span>And the bad shall be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note69a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>cast away</span>, yea, even out of all the land of my vineyard; for behold, only this once will I prune my vineyard.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357388" id="p70"><span class="verse-number">70 </span>And it came to pass that the Lord of the vineyard sent his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note70a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>servant</span>; and the servant went and did as the Lord had commanded him, and brought other <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note70b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>servants</span>; and they were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note70c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>few</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357389" id="p71"><span class="verse-number">71 </span>And the Lord of the vineyard said unto them: Go to, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note71a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>labor</span> in the vineyard, with your might. For behold, this is the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note71b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>last time</span> that I shall <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note71c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>nourish</span> my vineyard; for the end is nigh at hand, and the season speedily cometh; and if ye labor with your might with me ye shall have joy in the fruit which I shall lay up unto myself against the time which will soon come.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357390" id="p72"><span class="verse-number">72 </span>And it came to pass that the servants did go and labor with their mights; and the Lord of the vineyard labored also with them; and they did obey the commandments of the Lord of the vineyard in all things.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357391" id="p73"><span class="verse-number">73 </span>And there began to be the natural fruit again in the vineyard; and the natural branches began to grow and thrive exceedingly; and the wild branches began to be plucked off and to be cast away; and they did keep the root and the top thereof equal, according to the strength thereof.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357392" id="p74"><span class="verse-number">74 </span>And thus they labored, with all diligence, according to the commandments of the Lord of the vineyard, even until the bad had been cast away out of the vineyard, and the Lord had preserved unto himself that the trees had become again the natural fruit; and they became like unto <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note74a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>one</span> body; and the fruits were equal; and the Lord of the vineyard had preserved unto himself the natural fruit, which was most precious unto him from the beginning.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357393" id="p75"><span class="verse-number">75 </span>And it came to pass that when the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note75a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Lord</span> of the vineyard saw that his fruit was good, and that his vineyard was no more corrupt, he called up his servants, and said unto them: Behold, for this last time have we nourished my vineyard; and thou beholdest that I have done according to my will; and I have preserved the natural fruit, that it <span class="page-break" data-page="132"></span>is good, even like as it was in the beginning. And <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note75b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>blessed</span> art thou; for because ye have been diligent in laboring with me in my vineyard, and have kept my commandments, and have brought unto me again the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note75c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>natural</span> fruit, that my vineyard is no more corrupted, and the bad is cast away, behold ye shall have <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note75d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>joy</span> with me because of the fruit of my vineyard.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357394" id="p76"><span class="verse-number">76 </span>For behold, for a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note76a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>long</span> time will I lay up of the fruit of my vineyard unto mine own self against the season, which speedily cometh; and for the last time have I nourished my vineyard, and pruned it, and dug about it, and dunged it; wherefore I will lay up unto mine own self of the fruit, for a long time, according to that which I have spoken.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357395" id="p77"><span class="verse-number">77 </span>And when the time cometh that evil fruit shall again come into my vineyard, then will I cause the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note77a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>good</span> and the bad to be gathered; and the good will I preserve unto myself, and the bad will I cast away into its own place. And then cometh the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note77b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>season</span> and the end; and my vineyard will I cause to be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note77c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>burned</span> with <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note77d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>fire</span>.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Jacob 6	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128357458" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/jacob/6" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Jacob 6</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128357480" id="title_number1">Chapter 6</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128357481" id="study_summary1">The Lord will recover Israel in the last days—The world will be burned with fire—Men must follow Christ to avoid the lake of fire and brimstone. About 544–421 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357483" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now, behold, my brethren, as I said unto you that I would prophesy, behold, this is my prophecy—that the things which this prophet <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Zenos</span> spake, concerning the house of Israel, in the which he likened them unto a tame <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>olive tree</span>, must surely come to pass.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357484" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And the day that he shall set his hand again the second time to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>recover</span> his people, is the day, yea, even the last time, that the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>servants</span> of the Lord shall go forth in his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>power</span>, to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>nourish</span> and prune his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>vineyard</span>; and after that the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2f"><sup class="marker">f</sup>end</span> soon cometh.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357485" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And how <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>blessed</span> are they who have labored <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>diligently</span> in his vineyard; and how <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>cursed</span> are they who shall be cast out into their own place! And the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>world</span> shall be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>burned</span> with fire.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357486" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And how merciful is our God unto us, for he remembereth the house of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Israel</span>, both roots and branches; and he stretches forth his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>hands</span> unto them all the day long; and they are a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>stiffnecked</span> and a gainsaying people; but as many as will not harden their hearts shall be saved in the kingdom of God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357487" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>Wherefore, my beloved brethren, I beseech of you in words of soberness that ye would repent, and come with full purpose of heart, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>cleave</span> unto God as he cleaveth unto you. And while his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>arm</span> of mercy is extended towards you in <span class="page-break" data-page="133"></span>the light of the day, harden not your hearts.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357488" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>Yea, today, if ye will hear his voice, harden not your hearts; for why will ye <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>die</span>?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357489" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>For behold, after ye have been nourished by the good <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>word</span> of God all the day long, will ye bring forth evil fruit, that ye must be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>hewn</span> down and cast into the fire?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357490" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>Behold, will ye reject these words? Will ye reject the words of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>prophets</span>; and will ye reject all the words which have been spoken concerning Christ, after so many have spoken concerning him; and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>deny</span> the good word of Christ, and the power of God, and the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>gift</span> of the Holy Ghost, and quench the Holy Spirit, and make a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>mock</span> of the great plan of redemption, which hath been laid for you?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357491" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>Know ye not that if ye will do these things, that the power of the redemption and the resurrection, which is in Christ, will bring you to stand with <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>shame</span> and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>awful</span> <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>guilt</span> before the bar of God?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357492" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And according to the power of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>justice</span>, for justice cannot be denied, ye must go away into that <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>lake</span> of fire and brimstone, whose flames are unquenchable, and whose smoke ascendeth up forever and ever, which lake of fire and brimstone is <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>endless</span> <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>torment</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357493" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>O then, my beloved brethren, repent ye, and enter in at the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>strait gate</span>, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>continue</span> in the way which is narrow, until ye shall obtain eternal life.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357494" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>O be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>wise</span>; what can I say more?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128357495" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>Finally, I bid you farewell, until I shall meet you before the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>pleasing</span> bar of God, which bar striketh the wicked with <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>awful</span> dread and fear. Amen.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Jacob 7	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128356659" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/jacob/7" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Jacob 7</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128356660" id="title_number1">Chapter 7</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128356661" id="study_summary1">Sherem denies Christ, contends with Jacob, demands a sign, and is smitten of God—All of the prophets have spoken of Christ and His Atonement—The Nephites lived out their days as wanderers, born in tribulation, and hated by the Lamanites. About 544–421 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356662" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now it came to pass after some years had passed away, there came a man among the people of Nephi, whose name was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Sherem</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356663" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And it came to pass that he began to preach among the people, and to declare unto them that there should be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>no</span> Christ. And he preached many things which were flattering unto the people; and this he did that he might <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>overthrow</span> the doctrine of Christ.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356664" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And he labored diligently that he might lead away the hearts of the people, insomuch that he did lead away many hearts; and he knowing that I, Jacob, had faith in Christ who should come, he sought much opportunity that he might come unto me.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356665" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And he was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>learned</span>, that he had a perfect knowledge of the language of the people; wherefore, he could use much <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>flattery</span>, and much power of speech, according to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>power</span> of the devil.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356666" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And he had hope to shake me from the faith, notwithstanding the many <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>revelations</span> and the many things which I had seen concerning <span class="page-break" data-page="134"></span>these things; for I truly had seen <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>angels</span>, and they had ministered unto me. And also, I had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>heard</span> the voice of the Lord speaking unto me in very word, from time to time; wherefore, I could not be shaken.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356667" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And it came to pass that he came unto me, and on this wise did he speak unto me, saying: Brother Jacob, I have sought much opportunity that I might speak unto you; for I have heard and also know that thou goest about much, preaching that which ye call the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>gospel</span>, or the doctrine of Christ.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356668" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And ye have led away much of this people that they pervert the right way of God, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>keep</span> not the law of Moses which is the right way; and convert the law of Moses into the worship of a being which ye say shall come many hundred years hence. And now behold, I, Sherem, declare unto you that this is <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>blasphemy</span>; for no man knoweth of such things; for he cannot <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>tell</span> of things to come. And after this manner did Sherem contend against me.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356669" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>But behold, the Lord God poured in his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Spirit</span> into my soul, insomuch that I did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>confound</span> him in all his words.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356670" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And I said unto him: Deniest thou the Christ who shall come? And he said: If there should be a Christ, I would not deny him; but I know that there is no Christ, neither has been, nor ever will be.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356671" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And I said unto him: Believest thou the scriptures? And he said, Yea.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356672" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And I said unto him: Then ye do not understand them; for they truly testify of Christ. Behold, I say unto you that none of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>prophets</span> have written, nor <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>prophesied</span>, save they have spoken concerning this Christ.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356673" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And this is not all—it has been made manifest unto me, for I have heard and seen; and it also has been made manifest unto me by the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>power</span> of the Holy Ghost; wherefore, I know if there should be no atonement made all mankind must be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>lost</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356674" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And it came to pass that he said unto me: Show me a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>sign</span> by this power of the Holy Ghost, in the which ye know so much.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356675" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And I said unto him: What am I that I should <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>tempt</span> God to show unto thee a sign in the thing which thou knowest to be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>true</span>? Yet thou wilt deny it, because thou art of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>devil</span>. Nevertheless, not my will be done; but if God shall smite thee, let that be a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>sign</span> unto thee that he has power, both in heaven and in earth; and also, that Christ shall come. And thy will, O Lord, be done, and not mine.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356676" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And it came to pass that when I, Jacob, had spoken these words, the power of the Lord came upon him, insomuch that he fell to the earth. And it came to pass that he was nourished for the space of many days.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356677" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And it came to pass that he said unto the people: Gather together on the morrow, for I shall die; wherefore, I desire to speak unto the people before I shall die.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356678" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>And it came to pass that on the morrow the multitude were gathered together; and he spake plainly unto them and denied the things which he had taught them, and confessed the Christ, and the power <span class="page-break" data-page="135"></span>of the Holy Ghost, and the ministering of angels.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356679" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And he spake plainly unto them, that he had been <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note18a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>deceived</span> by the power of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note18b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>devil</span>. And he spake of hell, and of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note18c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>eternity</span>, and of eternal <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note18d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>punishment</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356680" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>And he said: I <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>fear</span> lest I have committed the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>unpardonable sin</span>, for I have lied unto God; for I denied the Christ, and said that I believed the scriptures; and they truly testify of him. And because I have thus lied unto God I greatly fear lest my case shall be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>awful</span>; but I confess unto God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356681" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>And it came to pass that when he had said these words he could say no more, and he <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>gave</span> up the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>ghost</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356682" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And when the multitude had witnessed that he spake these things as he was about to give up the ghost, they were astonished exceedingly; insomuch that the power of God came down upon them, and they were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>overcome</span> that they fell to the earth.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356683" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>Now, this thing was pleasing unto me, Jacob, for I had requested it of my Father who was in heaven; for he had heard my cry and answered my prayer.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356684" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>And it came to pass that peace and the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>love</span> of God was restored again among the people; and they <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>searched</span> the scriptures, and hearkened no more to the words of this wicked man.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356685" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>And it came to pass that many means were devised to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>reclaim</span> and restore the Lamanites to the knowledge of the truth; but it all was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>vain</span>, for they delighted in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>wars</span> and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>bloodshed</span>, and they had an eternal <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>hatred</span> against us, their brethren. And they sought by the power of their arms to destroy us continually.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356686" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>Wherefore, the people of Nephi did fortify against them with their arms, and with all their might, trusting in the God and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>rock</span> of their salvation; wherefore, they became as yet, conquerors of their enemies.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356687" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>And it came to pass that I, Jacob, began to be old; and the record of this people being kept on the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>other plates</span> of Nephi, wherefore, I conclude this record, declaring that I have written according to the best of my knowledge, by saying that the time passed away with us, and also our <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>lives</span> passed away like as it were unto us a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>dream</span>, we being a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>lonesome</span> and a solemn people, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>wanderers</span>, cast out from Jerusalem, born in tribulation, in a wilderness, and hated of our brethren, which caused wars and contentions; wherefore, we did mourn out our days.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356688" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>And I, Jacob, saw that I must soon go down to my grave; wherefore, I said unto my son <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Enos</span>: Take these <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>plates</span>. And I told him the things which my brother Nephi had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>commanded</span> me, and he promised obedience unto the commands. And I make an end of my writing upon these plates, which writing has been <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>small</span>; and to the reader I bid farewell, hoping that many of my brethren may read my words. Brethren, adieu.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Enos 1	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128354253" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/enos/1" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Enos 1</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="136"></span>^N			<h1 data-aid="128354254" id="title1"><span class="dominant">The Book of Enos</span></h1>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128354255" id="title_number1">Chapter 1</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128354256" id="study_summary1">Enos prays mightily and gains a remission of his sins—The voice of the Lord comes into his mind, promising salvation for the Lamanites in a future day—The Nephites sought to reclaim the Lamanites—Enos rejoices in his Redeemer. About 420 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354257" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>Behold, it came to pass that I, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Enos</span>, knowing my father that <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>he</span> was a just man—for he <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>taught</span> me in his language, and also in the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>nurture</span> and admonition of the Lord—and blessed be the name of my God for it—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354258" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And I will tell you of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>wrestle</span> which I had before God, before I received a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>remission</span> of my sins.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354259" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>Behold, I went to hunt beasts in the forests; and the words which I had often heard my father speak concerning eternal life, and the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>joy</span> of the saints, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>sunk</span> deep into my heart.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354260" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And my soul <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>hungered</span>; and I <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>kneeled</span> down before my Maker, and I <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>cried</span> unto him in mighty <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>prayer</span> and supplication for mine own soul; and all the day long did I cry unto him; yea, and when the night came I did still raise my voice high that it reached the heavens.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354261" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And there came a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>voice</span> unto me, saying: Enos, thy sins are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>forgiven</span> thee, and thou shalt be blessed.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354262" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And I, Enos, knew that God <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>could</span> not lie; wherefore, my guilt was swept away.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354263" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And I said: Lord, how is it done?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354264" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And he said unto me: <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Because</span> of thy <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>faith</span> in Christ, whom thou hast never before heard nor seen. And many years pass away before he shall manifest himself in the flesh; wherefore, go to, thy faith hath made thee <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>whole</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354265" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>Now, it came to pass that when I had heard these words I began to feel a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>desire</span> for the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>welfare</span> of my brethren, the Nephites; wherefore, I did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>pour out</span> my whole soul unto God for them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354266" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And while I was thus struggling in the spirit, behold, the voice of the Lord came into my <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>mind</span> again, saying: I will visit thy brethren according to their diligence in keeping my commandments. I have <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>given</span> unto them this land, and it is a holy land; and I <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>curse</span> it not save it be for the cause of iniquity; wherefore, I will visit thy brethren according as I have said; and their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>transgressions</span> will I bring down with sorrow upon their own heads.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354267" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And after I, Enos, had heard these words, my <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>faith</span> began to be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>unshaken</span> in the Lord; and I <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>prayed</span> unto him with many long <span class="page-break" data-page="137"></span><span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>strugglings</span> for my brethren, the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354268" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And it came to pass that after I had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>prayed</span> and labored with all diligence, the Lord said unto me: I will grant unto thee according to thy <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>desires</span>, because of thy faith.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354269" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And now behold, this was the desire which I desired of him—that if it should so be, that my people, the Nephites, should fall into transgression, and by any means be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>destroyed</span>, and the Lamanites should not be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>destroyed</span>, that the Lord God would <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>preserve</span> a record of my people, the Nephites; even if it so be by the power of his holy arm, that it might be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>brought forth</span> at some future day unto the Lamanites, that, perhaps, they might be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>brought</span> unto salvation—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354270" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>For at the present our strugglings were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>vain</span> in restoring them to the true faith. And they swore in their wrath that, if it were possible, they would <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>destroy</span> our records and us, and also all the traditions of our fathers.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354271" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>Wherefore, I knowing that the Lord God was able to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>preserve</span> our records, I cried unto him continually, for he had said unto me: Whatsoever thing ye shall ask in faith, believing that ye shall receive in the name of Christ, ye shall receive it.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354272" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And I had faith, and I did cry unto God that he would <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>preserve</span> the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>records</span>; and he covenanted with me that he would <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>bring</span> <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>them</span> forth unto the Lamanites in his own due time.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354273" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>And I, Enos, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>knew</span> it would be according to the covenant which he had made; wherefore my soul did rest.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354274" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And the Lord said unto me: Thy fathers have also required of me this thing; and it shall be done unto them according to their faith; for their faith was like unto thine.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354275" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>And now it came to pass that I, Enos, went about among the people of Nephi, prophesying of things to come, and testifying of the things which I had heard and seen.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354276" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>And I bear record that the people of Nephi did seek diligently to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>restore</span> the Lamanites unto the true faith in God. But our <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>labors</span> were vain; their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>hatred</span> was fixed, and they were led by their evil nature that they became wild, and ferocious, and a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>blood-thirsty</span> people, full of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>idolatry</span> and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20f"><sup class="marker">f</sup>filthiness</span>; feeding upon beasts of prey; dwelling in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20g"><sup class="marker">g</sup>tents</span>, and wandering about in the wilderness with a short skin girdle about their loins and their heads shaven; and their skill was in the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20h"><sup class="marker">h</sup>bow</span>, and in the cimeter, and the ax. And many of them did eat nothing save it was raw meat; and they were continually seeking to destroy us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354277" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And it came to pass that the people of Nephi did till the land, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>raise</span> all manner of grain, and of fruit, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>flocks</span> of herds, and flocks of all manner of cattle of every kind, and goats, and wild goats, and also many horses.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354278" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>And there were exceedingly <span class="page-break" data-page="138"></span>many <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note22a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>prophets</span> among us. And the people were a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note22b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>stiffnecked</span> people, hard to understand.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354279" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>And there was nothing save it was exceeding <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>harshness</span>, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>preaching</span> and prophesying of wars, and contentions, and destructions, and continually <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>reminding</span> them of death, and the duration of eternity, and the judgments and the power of God, and all these things—stirring them up <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>continually</span> to keep them in the fear of the Lord. I say there was nothing short of these things, and exceedingly great plainness of speech, would keep them from going down speedily to destruction. And after this manner do I write concerning them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354280" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>And I saw <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>wars</span> between the Nephites and Lamanites in the course of my days.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354281" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>And it came to pass that I began to be old, and an hundred and seventy and nine years had passed away from the time that our father Lehi <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>left</span> Jerusalem.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354282" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>And I saw that I <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>must</span> soon go down to my grave, having been wrought upon by the power of God that I must preach and prophesy unto this people, and declare the word according to the truth which is in Christ. And I have declared it in all my days, and have rejoiced in it above that of the world.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354283" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>And I soon go to the place of my <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>rest</span>, which is with my Redeemer; for I know that in him I shall <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>rest</span>. And I rejoice in the day when my <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>mortal</span> shall put on <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>immortality</span>, and shall stand before him; then shall I see his face with pleasure, and he will say unto me: Come unto me, ye blessed, there is a place prepared for you in the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>mansions</span> of my Father. Amen.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Jarom 1	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128356740" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/jarom/1" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Jarom 1</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<h1 data-aid="128356741" id="title1"><span class="dominant">The Book of Jarom</span></h1>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128356742" id="title_number1">Chapter 1</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128356743" id="study_summary1">The Nephites keep the law of Moses, look forward to the coming of Christ, and prosper in the land—Many prophets labor to keep the people in the way of truth. About 399–361 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356744" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>Now behold, I, Jarom, write a few words according to the commandment of my father, Enos, that our <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>genealogy</span> may be kept.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356745" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And as <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>these plates</span> are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>small</span>, and as these things are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>written</span> for the intent of the benefit of our brethren the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>Lamanites</span>, wherefore, it must needs be that I write a little; but I shall not write the things of my prophesying, nor of my revelations. For what could I write more than my fathers have written? For have not they revealed the plan of salvation? I say unto you, Yea; and this sufficeth me.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356746" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>Behold, it is expedient that much <span class="page-break" data-page="139"></span>should be done among this people, because of the hardness of their hearts, and the deafness of their ears, and the blindness of their minds, and the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>stiffness</span> of their necks; nevertheless, God is exceedingly merciful unto them, and has not as yet <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>swept</span> them off from the face of the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356747" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And there are many among us who have many <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>revelations</span>, for they are not all <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>stiffnecked</span>. And as many as are not stiffnecked and have faith, have <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>communion</span> with the Holy Spirit, which maketh manifest unto the children of men, according to their faith.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356748" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And now, behold, two hundred years had passed away, and the people of Nephi had waxed strong in the land. They observed to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>keep</span> the law of Moses and the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>sabbath</span> day holy unto the Lord. And they <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>profaned</span> not; neither did they <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>blaspheme</span>. And the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>laws</span> of the land were exceedingly strict.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356749" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And they were scattered upon <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>much</span> of the face of the land, and the Lamanites also. And they were exceedingly more <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>numerous</span> than were they of the Nephites; and they loved <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>murder</span> and would drink the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>blood</span> of beasts.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356750" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And it came to pass that they came many times against us, the Nephites, to battle. But our <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>kings</span> and our <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>leaders</span> were mighty men in the faith of the Lord; and they taught the people the ways of the Lord; wherefore, we withstood the Lamanites and swept them away out of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>our</span> lands, and began to fortify our cities, or whatsoever place of our inheritance.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356751" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And we multiplied exceedingly, and spread upon the face of the land, and became exceedingly rich in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>gold</span>, and in silver, and in precious things, and in fine <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>workmanship</span> of wood, in buildings, and in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>machinery</span>, and also in iron and copper, and brass and steel, making all manner of tools of every kind to till the ground, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>weapons</span> of war—yea, the sharp pointed arrow, and the quiver, and the dart, and the javelin, and all preparations for war.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356752" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And thus being prepared to meet the Lamanites, they did not prosper against us. But the word of the Lord was verified, which he spake unto our fathers, saying that: <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Inasmuch</span> as ye will keep my commandments ye shall <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>prosper</span> in the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356753" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And it came to pass that the prophets of the Lord did threaten the people of Nephi, according to the word of God, that if they did not keep the commandments, but should fall into transgression, they should be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>destroyed</span> from off the face of the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356754" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>Wherefore, the prophets, and the priests, and the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>teachers</span>, did labor diligently, exhorting with all long-suffering the people to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>diligence</span>; teaching the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>law</span> of Moses, and the intent for which it was given; persuading them to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>look</span> forward unto the Messiah, and believe in him to come <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>as</span> though he <span class="page-break" data-page="140"></span>already was. And after this manner did they teach them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356755" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And it came to pass that by so doing they kept them from being <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>destroyed</span> upon the face of the land; for they did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>prick</span> their hearts with the word, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>continually</span> stirring them up unto repentance.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356756" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And it came to pass that two hundred and thirty and eight years had passed away—after the manner of wars, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>contentions</span>, and dissensions, for the space of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>much</span> of the time.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356757" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And I, Jarom, do not write more, for the plates are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>small</span>. But behold, my brethren, ye can go to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>other plates</span> of Nephi; for behold, upon them the records of our wars are engraven, according to the writings of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>kings</span>, or those which they caused to be written.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356758" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And I deliver these plates into the hands of my son Omni, that they may be kept according to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>commandments</span> of my fathers.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Omni 1	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128360327" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/omni/1" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Omni 1</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<h1 data-aid="128360328" id="title1"><span class="dominant">The Book of Omni</span></h1>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128360329" id="title_number1">Chapter 1</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128360330" id="study_summary1">Omni, Amaron, Chemish, Abinadom, and Amaleki, each in turn, keep the records—Mosiah discovers the people of Zarahemla, who came from Jerusalem in the days of Zedekiah—Mosiah is made king over them—The descendants of Mulek at Zarahemla had discovered Coriantumr, the last of the Jaredites—King Benjamin succeeds Mosiah—Men should offer their souls as an offering to Christ. About 323–130 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360331" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>Behold, it came to pass that I, Omni, being commanded by my father, Jarom, that I should write somewhat upon <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>these plates</span>, to preserve our genealogy—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360332" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>Wherefore, in my days, I would that ye should know that I fought much with the sword to preserve my people, the Nephites, from falling into the hands of their enemies, the Lamanites. But behold, I of myself <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>am</span> a wicked man, and I have not kept the statutes and the commandments of the Lord as I ought to have done.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360333" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And it came to pass that two hundred and seventy and six years had passed away, and we had many seasons of peace; and we had many <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>seasons</span> of serious war and bloodshed. Yea, and in fine, two hundred and eighty and two years had passed away, and I had kept these plates according to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>commandments</span> of my <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>fathers</span>; and I <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>conferred</span> them upon my son Amaron. And I make an end.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360334" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And now I, Amaron, write the things whatsoever I write, which are few, in the book of my father.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360335" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>Behold, it came to pass that three hundred and twenty years had passed away, and the more wicked part of the Nephites were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>destroyed</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360336" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>For the Lord would not suffer, after he had led them out of the land of Jerusalem and kept and preserved them from falling into the hands of their enemies, yea, he would not suffer that the words should not be verified, which he <span class="page-break" data-page="141"></span>spake unto our fathers, saying that: <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Inasmuch</span> as ye will not keep my commandments ye shall not <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>prosper</span> in the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360337" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>Wherefore, the Lord did visit them in great judgment; nevertheless, he did spare the righteous that they should not perish, but did deliver them out of the hands of their enemies.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360338" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And it came to pass that I did deliver the plates unto my brother Chemish.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360339" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>Now I, Chemish, write what few things I write, in the same book with my brother; for behold, I saw the last which he wrote, that he wrote it with his own hand; and he wrote it in the day that he delivered them unto me. And after this manner we keep the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>records</span>, for it is according to the commandments of our fathers. And I make an end.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360340" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>Behold, I, Abinadom, am the son of Chemish. Behold, it came to pass that I saw much war and contention between my people, the Nephites, and the Lamanites; and I, with my own sword, have taken the lives of many of the Lamanites in the defence of my brethren.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360341" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And behold, the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>record</span> of this people is engraven upon plates which is had by the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>kings</span>, according to the generations; and I know of no revelation save that which has been written, neither prophecy; wherefore, that which is sufficient is written.
