the mortal body—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360134" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>I say, that this is the man who receiveth salvation, through the atonement which was prepared from the foundation of the world for all mankind, which ever were since the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>fall</span> of Adam, or who are, or who ever shall be, even unto the end of the world.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360135" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And this is the means whereby salvation cometh. And there is <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>none</span> other salvation save this which hath been spoken of; neither are there any conditions whereby man can be saved except the conditions which I have told you.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360136" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>Believe in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>God</span>; believe that he is, and that he <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>created</span> all things, both in heaven and in earth; believe that he has all <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>wisdom</span>, and all power, both in heaven and in earth; believe that man doth not <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>comprehend</span> all the things which the Lord can comprehend.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360137" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And again, believe that ye must <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>repent</span> of your sins and forsake them, and humble yourselves before God; and ask in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>sincerity</span> of heart that he would <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>forgive</span> you; and now, if you <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>believe</span> all these things see that ye <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>do</span> them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360138" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And again I say unto you as I have said before, that as ye have come to the knowledge of the glory of God, or if ye have known of his goodness and have <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>tasted</span> of his love, and have received a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>remission</span> of your sins, which causeth such exceedingly great joy in your souls, even so I would that ye should remember, and always retain in remembrance, the greatness of God, and your own <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>nothingness</span>, and his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>goodness</span> and long-suffering towards you, unworthy creatures, and humble yourselves even in the depths of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>humility</span>, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11f"><sup class="marker">f</sup>calling</span> on the name of the Lord daily, and standing <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11g"><sup class="marker">g</sup>steadfastly</span> in the faith of that which is to come, which was spoken by the mouth of the angel.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360139" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And behold, I say unto you that if ye do this ye shall always rejoice, and be filled with the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>love</span> of God, and always <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>retain</span> a remission of your sins; and ye shall grow in the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>knowledge</span> of the glory of him that created you, or in the knowledge of that which is just and true.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360140" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And ye will not have a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>mind</span> to injure one another, but to live <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>peaceably</span>, and to render to every <span class="page-break" data-page="156"></span>man according to that which is his due.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360141" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And ye will not suffer your <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>children</span> that they go hungry, or naked; neither will ye <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>suffer</span> that they transgress the laws of God, and fight and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>quarrel</span> one with another, and serve the devil, who is the master of sin, or who is the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>evil spirit</span> which hath been spoken of by our fathers, he being an enemy to all righteousness.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360142" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>But ye will <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>teach</span> them to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>walk</span> in the ways of truth and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>soberness</span>; ye will teach them to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>love</span> one another, and to serve one another.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360143" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And also, ye yourselves will <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>succor</span> those that stand in need of your succor; ye will administer of your substance unto him that standeth in need; and ye will not suffer that the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>beggar</span> putteth up his petition to you in vain, and turn him out to perish.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360144" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>Perhaps thou shalt <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>say</span>: The man has brought upon himself his misery; therefore I will stay my hand, and will not give unto him of my food, nor impart unto him of my substance that he may not suffer, for his punishments are just—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360145" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>But I say unto you, O man, whosoever doeth this the same hath great cause to repent; and except he repenteth of that which he hath done he perisheth forever, and hath no interest in the kingdom of God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360146" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>For behold, are we not all <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>beggars</span>? Do we not all depend upon the same Being, even God, for all the substance which we have, for both food and raiment, and for gold, and for silver, and for all the riches which we have of every kind?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360147" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>And behold, even at this time, ye have been calling on his name, and begging for a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>remission</span> of your sins. And has he suffered that ye have begged in vain? Nay; he has poured out his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Spirit</span> upon you, and has caused that your hearts should be filled with <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>joy</span>, and has caused that your mouths should be stopped that ye could not find utterance, so exceedingly great was your joy.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360148" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And now, if God, who has created you, on whom you are dependent for your lives and for all that ye have and are, doth grant unto you whatsoever ye ask that is right, in faith, believing that ye shall receive, O then, how ye ought to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>impart</span> of the substance that ye have one to another.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360149" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>And if ye <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note22a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>judge</span> the man who putteth up his petition to you for your substance that he perish not, and condemn him, how much more just will be your <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note22b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>condemnation</span> for withholding your substance, which doth not belong to you but to God, to whom also your life <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note22c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>belongeth</span>; and yet ye put up no petition, nor repent of the thing which thou hast done.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360150" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>I say unto you, wo be unto that man, for his substance shall perish with him; and now, I say these things unto those who are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>rich</span> as pertaining to the things of this world.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360151" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>And again, I say unto the poor, ye who have not and yet have sufficient, that ye remain from day to day; I mean all you who deny <span class="page-break" data-page="157"></span>the beggar, because ye have not; I would that ye say in your hearts that: I <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>give</span> not because I <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>have</span> not, but if I had I would <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>give</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360152" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>And now, if ye say this in your hearts ye remain guiltless, otherwise ye are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>condemned</span>; and your condemnation is just for ye covet that which ye have not received.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360153" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>And now, for the sake of these things which I have spoken unto you—that is, for the sake of retaining a remission of your sins from day to day, that ye may <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>walk</span> guiltless before God—I would that ye should <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>impart</span> of your substance to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>poor</span>, every man according to that which he hath, such as <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>feeding</span> the hungry, clothing the naked, visiting the sick and administering to their relief, both spiritually and temporally, according to their wants.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360154" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>And see that all these things are done in wisdom and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>order</span>; for it is not requisite that a man should run <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>faster</span> than he has strength. And again, it is expedient that he should be diligent, that thereby he might win the prize; therefore, all things must be done in order.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360155" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>And I would that ye should remember, that whosoever among you <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note28a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>borroweth</span> of his neighbor should return the thing that he borroweth, according as he doth agree, or else thou shalt commit sin; and perhaps thou shalt cause thy neighbor to commit sin also.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360156" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>And finally, I cannot tell you all the things whereby ye may commit sin; for there are divers ways and means, even so many that I cannot number them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360157" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>But this much I can tell you, that if ye do not <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note30a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>watch</span> yourselves, and your <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note30b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>thoughts</span>, and your <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note30c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>words</span>, and your deeds, and observe the commandments of God, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note30d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>continue</span> in the faith of what ye have heard concerning the coming of our Lord, even unto the end of your lives, ye must perish. And now, O man, remember, and perish not.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Mosiah 5	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128360234" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/mosiah/5" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Mosiah 5</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128360235" id="title_number1">Chapter 5</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128360236" id="study_summary1">The Saints become the sons and daughters of Christ through faith—They are then called by the name of Christ—King Benjamin exhorts them to be steadfast and immovable in good works. About 124 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360237" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now, it came to pass that when king Benjamin had thus spoken to his people, he sent among them, desiring to know of his people if they <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>believed</span> the words which he had spoken unto them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360238" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And they all cried with one voice, saying: Yea, we believe all the words which thou hast spoken unto us; and also, we know of their surety and truth, because of the Spirit of the Lord Omnipotent, which has wrought a mighty <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>change</span> in us, or in our hearts, that we have no more disposition to do <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>evil</span>, but to do good continually.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360239" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And we, ourselves, also, through the infinite <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>goodness</span> of God, and the manifestations of his Spirit, have great views of that which is to come; and were it expedient, we could prophesy of all things.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360240" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And it is the faith which we have had on the things which our king has spoken unto us that has brought <span class="page-break" data-page="158"></span>us to this great knowledge, whereby we do rejoice with such exceedingly great joy.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360241" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And we are willing to enter into a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>covenant</span> with our God to do his will, and to be obedient to his commandments in all things that he shall command us, all the remainder of our days, that we may not bring upon ourselves a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>never-ending</span> torment, as has been spoken by the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>angel</span>, that we may not drink out of the cup of the wrath of God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360242" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And now, these are the words which king Benjamin desired of them; and therefore he said unto them: Ye have spoken the words that I desired; and the covenant which ye have made is a righteous covenant.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360243" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And now, because of the covenant which ye have made ye shall be called the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>children</span> of Christ, his sons, and his daughters; for behold, this day he hath spiritually begotten you; for ye say that your hearts are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>changed</span> through faith on his name; therefore, ye are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>born</span> of him and have become his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>sons</span> and his daughters.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360244" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And under this head ye are made <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>free</span>, and there is <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>no</span> other head whereby ye can be made free. There is no other <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>name</span> given whereby salvation cometh; therefore, I would that ye should <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>take upon</span> you the name of Christ, all you that have entered into the covenant with God that ye should be obedient unto the end of your lives.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360245" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And it shall come to pass that whosoever doeth this shall be found at the right hand of God, for he shall know the name by which he is called; for he shall be called by the name of Christ.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360246" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And now it shall come to pass, that whosoever shall not take upon him the name of Christ must be called by some <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>other</span> name; therefore, he findeth himself on the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>left</span> hand of God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360247" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And I would that ye should remember also, that this is the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>name</span> that I said I should give unto you that never should be blotted out, except it be through transgression; therefore, take heed that ye do not transgress, that the name be not blotted out of your hearts.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360248" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>I say unto you, I would that ye should remember to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>retain</span> the name written always in your hearts, that ye are not found on the left hand of God, but that ye hear and know the voice by which ye shall be called, and also, the name by which he shall call you.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360249" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>For how <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>knoweth</span> a man the master whom he has not served, and who is a stranger unto him, and is far from the thoughts and intents of his heart?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360250" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And again, doth a man take an ass which belongeth to his neighbor, and keep him? I say unto you, Nay; he will not even suffer that he shall feed among his flocks, but will drive him away, and cast him out. I say unto you, that even so shall it be among you if ye know not the name by which ye are called.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360251" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>Therefore, I would that ye should be steadfast and immovable, always abounding in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>good works</span>, that Christ, the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Lord God Omnipotent</span>, <span class="page-break" data-page="159"></span>may <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>seal</span> you his, that you may be brought to heaven, that ye may have everlasting salvation and eternal life, through the wisdom, and power, and justice, and mercy of him who <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>created</span> all things, in heaven and in earth, who is God above all. Amen.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Mosiah 6	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128361038" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/mosiah/6" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Mosiah 6</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128361039" id="title_number1">Chapter 6</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128361040" id="study_summary1">King Benjamin records the names of the people and appoints priests to teach them—Mosiah reigns as a righteous king. About 124–121 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361041" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now, king Benjamin thought it was expedient, after having finished speaking to the people, that he should <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>take</span> the names of all those who had entered into a covenant with God to keep his commandments.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361042" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And it came to pass that there was not one soul, except it were little children, but who had entered into the covenant and had taken upon them the name of Christ.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361043" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And again, it came to pass that when king Benjamin had made an end of all these things, and had consecrated his son <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Mosiah</span> to be a ruler and a king over his people, and had given him all the charges concerning the kingdom, and also had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>appointed</span> <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>priests</span> to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>teach</span> the people, that thereby they might hear and know the commandments of God, and to stir them up in remembrance of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>oath</span> which they had made, he dismissed the multitude, and they returned, every one, according to their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3f"><sup class="marker">f</sup>families</span>, to their own houses.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361044" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And Mosiah began to reign in his father’s stead. And he began to reign in the thirtieth year of his age, making in the whole, about four hundred and seventy-six years from the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>time</span> that Lehi left Jerusalem.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361045" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And king Benjamin lived three years and he died.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361046" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And it came to pass that king Mosiah did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>walk</span> in the ways of the Lord, and did observe his judgments and his statutes, and did keep his commandments in all things whatsoever he commanded him.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361047" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And king Mosiah did cause his people that they should till the earth. And he also, himself, did till the earth, that thereby he might <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>not</span> become burdensome to his people, that he might do according to that which his father had done in all things. And there was no contention among all his people for the space of three years.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Mosiah 7	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128361067" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/mosiah/7" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Mosiah 7</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128361068" id="title_number1">Chapter 7</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128361069" id="study_summary1">Ammon finds the land of Lehi-Nephi, where Limhi is king—Limhi’s people are in bondage to the Lamanites—Limhi recounts their history—A prophet (Abinadi) had testified that Christ is the God and Father of all things—Those who sow filthiness reap the whirlwind, and those who put their trust in the Lord will be delivered. About 121 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361070" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now, it came to pass that after king Mosiah had had continual peace for the space of three years, he was desirous to know concerning the people who <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>went</span> up to dwell in the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Lehi-Nephi</span>, or in the city of Lehi-Nephi; for his people had heard nothing from them from the time they left the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>Zarahemla</span>; therefore, they wearied him with their teasings.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361071" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And it came to pass that king Mosiah granted that sixteen of their strong men might go up to the land of Lehi-Nephi, to inquire concerning their brethren.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="160"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361072" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And it came to pass that on the morrow they started to go up, having with them one <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Ammon</span>, he being a strong and mighty man, and a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>descendant</span> of Zarahemla; and he was also their leader.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361073" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And now, they knew not the course they should travel in the wilderness to go up to the land of Lehi-Nephi; therefore they wandered many days in the wilderness, even <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>forty</span> days did they wander.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361074" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And when they had wandered forty days they came to a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>hill</span>, which is north of the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Shilom</span>, and there they pitched their tents.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361075" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Ammon</span> took three of his brethren, and their names were Amaleki, Helem, and Hem, and they went down into the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Nephi</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361076" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And behold, they met the king of the people who were in the land of Nephi, and in the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Shilom</span>; and they were surrounded by the king’s guard, and were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>taken</span>, and were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>bound</span>, and were committed to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>prison</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361077" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And it came to pass when they had been in prison two days they were again brought before the king, and their bands were loosed; and they stood before the king, and were permitted, or rather <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>commanded</span>, that they should answer the questions which he should ask them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361078" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And he said unto them: Behold, I am <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Limhi</span>, the son of Noah, who was the son of Zeniff, who came up out of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>land of Zarahemla</span> to inherit this land, which was the land of their fathers, who was made a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>king</span> by the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>voice</span> of the people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361079" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And now, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>I</span> desire to know the cause whereby ye were so bold as to come near the walls of the city, when I, myself, was with my guards without the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>gate</span>?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361080" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And now, for this cause have I suffered that ye should be preserved, that I might inquire of you, or else I should have caused that my guards should have put you to death. Ye are permitted to speak.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361081" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And now, when Ammon saw that he was permitted to speak, he went forth and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>bowed</span> himself before the king; and rising again he said: O king, I am very thankful before God this day that I am yet alive, and am permitted to speak; and I will endeavor to speak with boldness;</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361082" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>For I am assured that if ye had known me ye would not have suffered that I should have worn these bands. For I am Ammon, and am a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>descendant</span> of Zarahemla, and have come up out of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>land of Zarahemla</span> to inquire concerning our brethren, whom <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>Zeniff</span> brought up out of that land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361083" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And now, it came to pass that after Limhi had heard the words of Ammon, he was exceedingly <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>glad</span>, and said: Now, I know of a surety that my brethren who were in the land of Zarahemla are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>yet</span> alive. And now, I will rejoice; and on the morrow I will cause that my people shall rejoice also.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361084" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>For behold, we are in bondage to the Lamanites, and are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>taxed</span> with a tax which is grievous to be borne. And now, behold, our brethren will deliver us out of our <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>bondage</span>, or out of the hands of the <span class="page-break" data-page="161"></span>Lamanites, and we will be their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>slaves</span>; for it is better that we be slaves to the Nephites than to pay tribute to the king of the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361085" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And now, king Limhi commanded his guards that they should no more bind Ammon nor his brethren, but caused that they should go to the hill which was north of Shilom, and bring their brethren into the city, that thereby they might eat, and drink, and rest themselves from the labors of their journey; for they had suffered many things; they had suffered hunger, thirst, and fatigue.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361086" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>And now, it came to pass on the morrow that king Limhi sent a proclamation among all his people, that thereby they might gather themselves together to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>temple</span>, to hear the words which he should speak unto them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361087" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And it came to pass that when they had gathered themselves together that he <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note18a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>spake</span> unto them in this wise, saying: O ye, my people, lift up your heads and be comforted; for behold, the time is at hand, or is not far distant, when we shall no longer be in subjection to our enemies, notwithstanding our many strugglings, which have been in vain; yet I trust there <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note18b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>remaineth</span> an effectual struggle to be made.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361088" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>Therefore, lift up your heads, and rejoice, and put your <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>trust</span> in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>God</span>, in that God who was the God of Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob; and also, that God who <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>brought</span> the children of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>Israel</span> out of the land of Egypt, and caused that they should walk through the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>Red Sea</span> on dry ground, and fed them with <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19f"><sup class="marker">f</sup>manna</span> that they might not perish in the wilderness; and many more things did he do for them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361089" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>And again, that same God has brought our fathers <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>out</span> of the land of Jerusalem, and has kept and preserved his people even until now; and behold, it is <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>because</span> of our iniquities and abominations that he has brought us into bondage.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361090" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And ye all are witnesses this day, that Zeniff, who was made king over this people, he being <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>over-zealous</span> to inherit the land of his fathers, therefore being deceived by the cunning and craftiness of king Laman, who having entered into a treaty with king Zeniff, and having yielded up into his hands the possessions of a part of the land, or even the city of Lehi-Nephi, and the city of Shilom; and the land round about—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361091" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>And all this he did, for the sole purpose of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note22a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>bringing</span> this people into subjection or into bondage. And behold, we at this time do pay <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note22b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>tribute</span> to the king of the Lamanites, to the amount of one half of our corn, and our barley, and even all our grain of every kind, and one half of the increase of our flocks and our herds; and even one half of all we have or possess the king of the Lamanites doth exact of us, or our lives.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361092" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>And now, is not this grievous to be borne? And is not this, our affliction, great? Now behold, how great reason we have to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>mourn</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361093" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>Yea, I say unto you, great are the reasons which we have to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>mourn</span>; for behold how many of our brethren have been slain, and their blood has been spilt in vain, and all because of iniquity.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361094" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>For if this people had not fallen into transgression the Lord would not have suffered that this great evil should come upon them. But behold, <span class="page-break" data-page="162"></span>they would not hearken unto his words; but there arose contentions among them, even so much that they did shed blood among themselves.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361095" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>And a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>prophet</span> of the Lord have they <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>slain</span>; yea, a chosen man of God, who told them of their wickedness and abominations, and prophesied of many things which are to come, yea, even the coming of Christ.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361096" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>And because he said unto them that Christ was the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>God</span>, the Father of all things, and said that he should take upon him the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>image</span> of man, and it should be the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>image</span> after which man was created in the beginning; or in other words, he said that man was created after the image of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>God</span>, and that God should come down among the children of men, and take upon him flesh and blood, and go forth upon the face of the earth—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361097" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>And now, because he said this, they did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note28a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>put</span> him to death; and many more things did they do which brought down the wrath of God upon them. Therefore, who wondereth that they are in bondage, and that they are smitten with sore afflictions?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361098" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>For behold, the Lord hath said: I will not <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note29a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>succor</span> my people in the day of their transgression; but I will hedge up their ways that they prosper not; and their doings shall be as a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note29b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>stumbling block</span> before them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361099" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>And again, he saith: If my people shall sow <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note30a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>filthiness</span> they shall <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note30b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>reap</span> the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note30c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>chaff</span> thereof in the whirlwind; and the effect thereof is poison.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361100" id="p31"><span class="verse-number">31 </span>And again he saith: If my people shall sow filthiness they shall reap the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note31a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>east wind</span>, which bringeth immediate destruction.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361101" id="p32"><span class="verse-number">32 </span>And now, behold, the promise of the Lord is fulfilled, and ye are smitten and afflicted.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361102" id="p33"><span class="verse-number">33 </span>But if ye will <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note33a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>turn</span> to the Lord with full purpose of heart, and put your trust in him, and serve him with all <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note33b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>diligence</span> of mind, if ye do this, he will, according to his own will and pleasure, deliver you out of bondage.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Mosiah 8	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128360267" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/mosiah/8" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Mosiah 8</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128360268" id="title_number1">Chapter 8</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128360269" id="study_summary1">Ammon teaches the people of Limhi—He learns of the twenty-four Jaredite plates—Ancient records can be translated by seers—No gift is greater than seership. About 121 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360270" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And it came to pass that after king Limhi had made an end of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>speaking</span> to his people, for he spake many things unto them and only a few of them have I written in this book, he told his people all the things concerning their brethren who were in the land of Zarahemla.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360271" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And he caused that Ammon should stand up before the multitude, and rehearse unto them all that had happened unto their brethren from the time that <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Zeniff</span> went up out of the land even until the time that he <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>himself</span> came up out of the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360272" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And he also rehearsed unto them the last words which king Benjamin had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>taught</span> them, and explained them to the people of king Limhi, so that they might understand all the words which he spake.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="163"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360273" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And it came to pass that after he had done all this, that king Limhi dismissed the multitude, and caused that they should return every one unto his own house.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360274" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And it came to pass that he caused that the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>plates</span> which contained the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>record</span> of his people from the time that they left the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>land of Zarahemla</span>, should be brought before Ammon, that he might read them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360275" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>Now, as soon as Ammon had read the record, the king inquired of him to know if he could <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>interpret</span> languages, and Ammon told him that he could not.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360276" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And the king said unto him: Being grieved for the afflictions of my people, I caused that <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>forty</span> and three of my people should take a journey into the wilderness, that thereby they might find the land of Zarahemla, that we might appeal unto our brethren to deliver us out of bondage.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360277" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And they were lost in the wilderness for the space of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>many</span> days, yet they were diligent, and found not the land of Zarahemla but returned to this land, having traveled in a land among many waters, having discovered a land which was covered with <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>bones</span> of men, and of beasts, and was also covered with ruins of buildings of every kind, having discovered a land which had been peopled with a people who were as numerous as the hosts of Israel.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360278" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And for a testimony that the things that they had said are true they have brought <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>twenty-four</span> plates which are filled with engravings, and they are of pure gold.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360279" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And behold, also, they have brought <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>breastplates</span>, which are large, and they are of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>brass</span> and of copper, and are perfectly sound.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360280" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And again, they have brought swords, the hilts thereof have perished, and the blades thereof were cankered with rust; and there is no one in the land that is able to interpret the language or the engravings that are on the plates. Therefore I said unto thee: Canst thou translate?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360281" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And I say unto thee again: Knowest thou of any one that can translate? For I am desirous that these records should be translated into our language; for, perhaps, they will give us a knowledge of a remnant of the people who have been destroyed, from whence these records came; or, perhaps, they will give us a knowledge of this very people who have been destroyed; and I am desirous to know the cause of their destruction.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360282" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>Now Ammon said unto him: I can assuredly tell thee, O king, of a man that can <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>translate</span> the records; for he has wherewith that he can look, and translate all records that are of ancient date; and it is a gift from God. And the things are called <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>interpreters</span>, and no man can look in them except he be commanded, lest he should look for that he ought not and he should perish. And whosoever is commanded to look in them, the same is called <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>seer</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360283" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And behold, the king of the people who are in the land of Zarahemla is the man that is commanded to do these things, and who has this high gift from God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360284" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And the king said that a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>seer</span> is greater than a prophet.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360285" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And Ammon said that a seer is a revelator and a prophet also; and a gift which is greater can no man <span class="page-break" data-page="164"></span>have, except he should possess the power of God, which no man can; yet a man may have great power given him from God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360286" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>But a seer can know of things which are past, and also of things which are to come, and by them shall all things be revealed, or, rather, shall secret things be made manifest, and hidden things shall come to light, and things which are not known shall be made known by them, and also things shall be made known by them which otherwise could not be known.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360287" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>Thus God has provided a means that man, through faith, might work mighty miracles; therefore he becometh a great benefit to his fellow beings.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360288" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>And now, when Ammon had made an end of speaking these words the king rejoiced exceedingly, and gave thanks to God, saying: Doubtless a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>great</span> mystery is contained within these plates, and these interpreters were doubtless prepared for the purpose of unfolding all such mysteries to the children of men.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360289" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>O how marvelous are the works of the Lord, and how long doth he suffer with his people; yea, and how <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>blind</span> and impenetrable are the understandings of the children of men; for they will not seek wisdom, neither do they desire that <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>she</span> should rule over them!</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128360290" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>Yea, they are as a wild flock which fleeth from the shepherd, and scattereth, and are driven, and are devoured by the beasts of the forest.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Mosiah 9	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128361164" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/mosiah/9" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Mosiah 9</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="intro" data-aid="128361167" id="intro1"><span class="small-caps">The Record of Zeniff</span>—An account of his people, from the time they left the land of Zarahemla until the time that they were delivered out of the hands of the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="study-intro" data-aid="128361168" id="study_intro1">Comprising chapters 9 through 22.</p>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128361170" id="title_number1">Chapter 9</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128361171" id="study_summary1">Zeniff leads a group from Zarahemla to possess the land of Lehi-Nephi—The Lamanite king permits them to inherit the land—There is war between the Lamanites and Zeniff’s people. About 200–187 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361172" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span><span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>I</span>, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Zeniff</span>, having been taught in all the language of the Nephites, and having had a knowledge of the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>Nephi</span>, or of the land of our fathers’ first inheritance, and having been sent as a spy among the Lamanites that I might spy out their forces, that our army might come upon them and destroy them—but when I saw that which was good among them I was desirous that they should not be destroyed.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361173" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>Therefore, I contended with my brethren in the wilderness, for I would that our ruler should make a treaty with them; but he being an austere and a blood-thirsty man commanded that I should be slain; but I was rescued by the shedding of much blood; for father fought against father, and brother against brother, until the greater number of our army was destroyed in the wilderness; and we returned, those of us that were spared, to the land of Zarahemla, to relate that tale to their wives and their children.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361174" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And yet, I being <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>over-zealous</span> to inherit the land of our fathers, collected as many as were desirous to go up to possess the land, and started again on our <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>journey</span> into the wilderness to go up to the land; but we were smitten with famine and sore afflictions; for we were slow to remember the Lord our God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361175" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>Nevertheless, after many days’ wandering in the wilderness we pitched our tents in the place where our brethren were slain, which was near to the land of our fathers.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361176" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And it came to pass that I went again with four of my men into the <span class="page-break" data-page="165"></span>city, in unto the king, that I might know of the disposition of the king, and that I might know if I might go in with my people and possess the land in peace.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361177" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And I went in unto the king, and he covenanted with me that I might possess the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>land of Lehi-Nephi</span>, and the land of Shilom.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361178" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And he also commanded that his people should depart out of the land, and I and my people went into the land that we might possess it.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361179" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And we began to build buildings, and to repair the walls of the city, yea, even the walls of the city of Lehi-Nephi, and the city of Shilom.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361180" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And we began to till the ground, yea, even with all manner of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>seeds</span>, with seeds of corn, and of wheat, and of barley, and with neas, and with sheum, and with seeds of all manner of fruits; and we did begin to multiply and prosper in the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361181" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>Now it was the cunning and the craftiness of king <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Laman</span>, to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>bring</span> my people into bondage, that he yielded up the land that we might possess it.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361182" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>Therefore it came to pass, that after we had dwelt in the land for the space of twelve years that king Laman began to grow uneasy, lest by any means my people should <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>wax</span> strong in the land, and that they could not overpower them and bring them into bondage.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361183" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>Now they were a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>lazy</span> and an <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>idolatrous</span> people; therefore they were desirous to bring us into bondage, that they might glut themselves with the labors of our hands; yea, that they might feast themselves upon the flocks of our fields.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361184" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>Therefore it came to pass that king Laman began to stir up his people that they should contend with my people; therefore there began to be wars and contentions in the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361185" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>For, in the thirteenth year of my reign in the land of Nephi, away on the south of the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Shilom</span>, when my people were watering and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>feeding</span> their flocks, and tilling their lands, a numerous host of Lamanites came upon them and began to slay them, and to take off their flocks, and the corn of their fields.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361186" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>Yea, and it came to pass that they fled, all that were not overtaken, even into the city of Nephi, and did call upon me for protection.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361187" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And it came to pass that I did arm them with bows, and with arrows, with swords, and with cimeters, and with clubs, and with slings, and with all manner of weapons which we could invent, and I and my people did go forth against the Lamanites to battle.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361188" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>Yea, in the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>strength</span> of the Lord did we go forth to battle against the Lamanites; for I and my people did cry mightily to the Lord that he would <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>deliver</span> us out of the hands of our enemies, for we were awakened to a remembrance of the deliverance of our fathers.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361189" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And God did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note18a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>hear</span> our cries and did answer our prayers; and we did go forth in his might; yea, we did go forth against the Lamanites, and in one day and a night we did slay three thousand and forty-three; we did slay them even until we had driven them out of our land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128361190" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>And I, myself, with mine own hands, did help to bury their dead. And behold, to our great sorrow and lamentation, two hundred and seventy-nine of our brethren were slain.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Mosiah 10	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128359169" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/mosiah/10" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Mosiah 10</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="166"></span>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128359170" id="title_number1">Chapter 10</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128359171" id="study_summary1">King Laman dies—His people are wild and ferocious and believe in false traditions—Zeniff and his people prevail against them. About 187–160 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359172" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And it came to pass that we again began to establish the kingdom and we again began to possess the land in peace. And I caused that there should be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>weapons</span> of war made of every kind, that thereby I might have weapons for my people against the time the Lamanites should come up again to war against my people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359173" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And I set guards round about the land, that the Lamanites might not come upon us again unawares and destroy us; and thus I did guard my people and my flocks, and keep them from falling into the hands of our enemies.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359174" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And it came to pass that we did inherit the land of our fathers for many years, yea, for the space of twenty and two years.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359175" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And I did cause that the men should till the ground, and raise all manner of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>grain</span> and all manner of fruit of every kind.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359176" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And I did cause that the women should spin, and toil, and work, and work all manner of fine linen, yea, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>cloth</span> of every kind, that we might clothe our nakedness; and thus we did prosper in the land—thus we did have continual peace in the land for the space of twenty and two years.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359177" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And it came to pass that king <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Laman</span> died, and his son began to reign in his stead. And he began to stir his people up in rebellion against my people; therefore they began to prepare for war, and to come up to battle against my people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359178" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>But I had sent my spies out round about the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Shemlon</span>, that I might discover their preparations, that I might guard against them, that they might not come upon my people and destroy them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359179" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And it came to pass that they came up upon the north of the land of Shilom, with their numerous hosts, men <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>armed</span> with <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>bows</span>, and with arrows, and with swords, and with cimeters, and with stones, and with slings; and they had their heads shaved that they were naked; and they were girded with a leathern girdle about their loins.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359180" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And it came to pass that I caused that the women and children of my people should be hid in the wilderness; and I also caused that all my old men that could bear arms, and also all my young men that were able to bear arms, should gather themselves together to go to battle against the Lamanites; and I did place them in their ranks, every man according to his age.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359181" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And it came to pass that we did go up to battle against the Lamanites; and I, even I, in my old age, did go up to battle against the Lamanites. And it came to pass that we did go up in the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>strength</span> of the Lord to battle.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359182" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>Now, the Lamanites knew nothing concerning the Lord, nor the strength of the Lord, therefore they depended upon their own strength. Yet they were a strong people, as to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>strength</span> of men.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359183" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>They were a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>wild</span>, and ferocious, and a blood-thirsty people, believing in the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>tradition</span> of their fathers, which is this—Believing that they were driven out of the land of Jerusalem because of the iniquities of their fathers, and that they were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>wronged</span> in the wilderness by their brethren, and they were also wronged while crossing the sea;</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359184" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And again, that they were <span class="page-break" data-page="167"></span>wronged while in the land of their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>first</span> inheritance, after they had crossed the sea, and all this because that Nephi was more faithful in keeping the commandments of the Lord—therefore <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>he</span> was favored of the Lord, for the Lord heard his prayers and answered them, and he took the lead of their journey in the wilderness.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359185" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And his brethren were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>wroth</span> with him because they <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>understood</span> not the dealings of the Lord; they were also wroth with him upon the waters because they hardened their hearts against the Lord.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359186" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And again, they were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>wroth</span> with him when they had arrived in the promised land, because they said that he had taken the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>ruling</span> of the people out of their hands; and they sought to kill him.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359187" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And again, they were wroth with him because he departed into the wilderness as the Lord had commanded him, and took the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>records</span> which were engraven on the plates of brass, for they said that he <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>robbed</span> them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359188" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>And thus they have taught their children that they should hate them, and that they should murder them, and that they should rob and plunder them, and do all they could to destroy them; therefore they have an eternal hatred towards the children of Nephi.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359189" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>For this very cause has king Laman, by his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note18a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>cunning</span>, and lying craftiness, and his fair promises, deceived me, that I have brought this my people up into this land, that they may destroy them; yea, and we have suffered these many years in the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359190" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>And now I, Zeniff, after having told all these things unto my people concerning the Lamanites, I did stimulate them to go to battle with their might, putting their trust in the Lord; therefore, we did contend with them, face to face.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359191" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>And it came to pass that we did drive them again out of our land; and we slew them with a great slaughter, even so many that we did not number them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359192" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And it came to pass that we returned again to our own land, and my people again began to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>tend</span> their flocks, and to till their ground.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359193" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>And now I, being old, did confer the kingdom upon one of my sons; therefore, I say no more. And may the Lord <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note22a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>bless</span> my people. Amen.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Mosiah 11	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128359217" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/mosiah/11" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Mosiah 11</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128359218" id="title_number1">Chapter 11</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128359219" id="study_summary1">King Noah rules in wickedness—He revels in riotous living with his wives and concubines—Abinadi prophesies that the people will be taken into bondage—His life is sought by King Noah. About 160–150 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359220" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now it came to pass that Zeniff conferred the kingdom upon Noah, one of his sons; therefore Noah began to reign in his stead; and he did not walk in the ways of his father.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359221" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>For behold, he did not keep the commandments of God, but he did walk after the desires of his own heart. And he had many wives and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>concubines</span>. And he did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>cause</span> his people to commit sin, and do that which was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>abominable</span> in the sight of the Lord. Yea, and they did commit <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>whoredoms</span> and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>all</span> manner of wickedness.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359222" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And he laid a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>tax</span> of one fifth part of all they possessed, a fifth part of their gold and of their silver, <span class="page-break" data-page="168"></span>and a fifth part of their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>ziff</span>, and of their copper, and of their brass and their iron; and a fifth part of their fatlings; and also a fifth part of all their grain.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359223" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And all this did he take to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>support</span> himself, and his wives and his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>concubines</span>; and also his priests, and their wives and their concubines; thus he had changed the affairs of the kingdom.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359224" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>For he put down all the priests that had been consecrated by his father, and consecrated new <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>ones</span> in their stead, such as were lifted up in the pride of their hearts.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359225" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>Yea, and thus they were supported in their laziness, and in their idolatry, and in their whoredoms, by the taxes which king Noah had put upon his people; thus did the people labor exceedingly to support iniquity.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359226" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>Yea, and they also became idolatrous, because they were deceived by the vain and flattering words of the king and priests; for they did speak flattering things unto them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359227" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And it came to pass that king Noah built many elegant and spacious buildings; and he ornamented them with fine work of wood, and of all manner of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>precious</span> things, of gold, and of silver, and of iron, and of brass, and of ziff, and of copper;</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359228" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And he also built him a spacious palace, and a throne in the midst thereof, all of which was of fine wood and was ornamented with gold and silver and with precious things.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359229" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And he also caused that his workmen should work all manner of fine work within the walls of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>temple</span>, of fine wood, and of copper, and of brass.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359230" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And the seats which were set apart for the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>high priests</span>, which were above all the other seats, he did ornament with pure gold; and he caused a breastwork to be built before them, that they might rest their bodies and their arms upon while they should speak lying and vain words to his people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128359231" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And it came to pass that he built a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>tower</span> near the temple; yea, a very high tower, even so high that he could stand upon the top thereof and overlook the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Shilom</span>, and also the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>Shemlon</span>, which was possessed by the Lamanites;
