therefore he appointed them to be chief captains over his armies.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352591" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And it came to pass that they took their camp, and moved forth toward the land of Zarahemla in the wilderness.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352592" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>Now it came to pass that while Amalickiah had thus been obtaining power by fraud and deceit, Moroni, on the other hand, had been <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>preparing</span> <span class="page-break" data-page="329"></span>the minds of the people to be faithful unto the Lord their God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352593" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>Yea, he had been strengthening the armies of the Nephites, and erecting small <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>forts</span>, or places of resort; throwing up banks of earth round about to enclose his armies, and also building <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>walls</span> of stone to encircle them about, round about their cities and the borders of their lands; yea, all round about the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352594" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And in their weakest fortifications he did place the greater number of men; and thus he did fortify and strengthen the land which was possessed by the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352595" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And thus he was preparing to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>support</span> their liberty, their lands, their wives, and their children, and their peace, and that they might live unto the Lord their God, and that they might maintain that which was called by their enemies the cause of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Christians</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352596" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And Moroni was a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>strong</span> and a mighty man; he was a man of a perfect <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>understanding</span>; yea, a man that did not delight in bloodshed; a man whose soul did joy in the liberty and the freedom of his country, and his brethren from bondage and slavery;</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352597" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>Yea, a man whose heart did swell with thanksgiving to his God, for the many privileges and blessings which he bestowed upon his people; a man who did labor exceedingly for the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>welfare</span> and safety of his people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352598" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>Yea, and he was a man who was firm in the faith of Christ, and he had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>sworn</span> with an oath to defend his people, his rights, and his country, and his religion, even to the loss of his blood.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352599" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>Now the Nephites were taught to defend themselves against their enemies, even to the shedding of blood if it were necessary; yea, and they were also taught <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>never</span> to give an offense, yea, and never to raise the sword except it were against an enemy, except it were to preserve their lives.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352600" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And this was their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>faith</span>, that by so doing God would <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>prosper</span> them in the land, or in other words, if they were faithful in keeping the commandments of God that he would prosper them in the land; yea, warn them to flee, or to prepare for war, according to their danger;</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352601" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And also, that God would make it known unto them <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>whither</span> they should go to defend themselves against their enemies, and by so doing, the Lord would deliver them; and this was the faith of Moroni, and his heart did glory in it; <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>not</span> in the shedding of blood but in doing good, in preserving his people, yea, in keeping the commandments of God, yea, and resisting iniquity.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352602" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>Yea, verily, verily I say unto you, if all men had been, and were, and ever would be, like unto <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Moroni</span>, behold, the very powers of hell would have been shaken forever; yea, the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>devil</span> would never have power over the hearts of the children of men.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352603" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>Behold, he was a man like unto <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note18a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Ammon</span>, the son of Mosiah, yea, and even the other sons of Mosiah, yea, and also Alma and his sons, for they were all men of God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352604" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>Now behold, Helaman and his brethren were no less <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>serviceable</span> unto the people than was Moroni; for they did preach the word of God, and they did baptize unto <span class="page-break" data-page="330"></span>repentance all men whosoever would hearken unto their words.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352605" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>And thus they went forth, and the people did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>humble</span> themselves because of their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>words</span>, insomuch that they were highly <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>favored</span> of the Lord, and thus they were free from wars and contentions among themselves, yea, even for the space of four years.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352606" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>But, as I have said, in the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>latter</span> end of the nineteenth year, yea, notwithstanding their peace amongst themselves, they were compelled reluctantly to contend with their brethren, the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352607" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>Yea, and in fine, their wars never did cease for the space of many years with the Lamanites, notwithstanding their much reluctance.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352608" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>Now, they were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>sorry</span> to take up arms against the Lamanites, because they did not delight in the shedding of blood; yea, and this was not all—they were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>sorry</span> to be the means of sending so many of their brethren out of this world into an eternal world, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>unprepared</span> to meet their God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352609" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>Nevertheless, they could not suffer to lay down their lives, that their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>wives</span> and their children should be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>massacred</span> by the barbarous <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>cruelty</span> of those who were once their brethren, yea, and had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>dissented</span> from their church, and had left them and had gone to destroy them by joining the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352610" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>Yea, they could not bear that their brethren should rejoice over the blood of the Nephites, so long as there were any who should keep the commandments of God, for the promise of the Lord was, if they should keep his commandments they should <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>prosper</span> in the land.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 49	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128353398" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/49" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 49</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128353399" id="title_number1">Chapter 49</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128353400" id="study_summary1">The invading Lamanites are unable to take the fortified cities of Ammonihah and Noah—Amalickiah curses God and swears to drink the blood of Moroni—Helaman and his brethren continue to strengthen the Church. About 72 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353401" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now it came to pass in the eleventh month of the nineteenth year, on the tenth day of the month, the armies of the Lamanites were seen approaching towards the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Ammonihah</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353402" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And behold, the city had been rebuilt, and Moroni had stationed an army by the borders of the city, and they had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>cast up</span> dirt round about to shield them from the arrows and the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>stones</span> of the Lamanites; for behold, they fought with stones and with arrows.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353403" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>Behold, I said that the city of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Ammonihah</span> had been rebuilt. I say unto you, yea, that it was in part rebuilt; and because the Lamanites had destroyed it once because of the iniquity of the people, they supposed that it would again become an easy prey for them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353404" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>But behold, how great was their disappointment; for behold, the Nephites had dug up a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>ridge</span> of earth round about them, which was so high that the Lamanites could not cast their stones and their arrows at them that they might take effect, neither could they come upon them save it was by their place of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>entrance</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353405" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>Now at this time the chief <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>captains</span> of the Lamanites were astonished exceedingly, because of the wisdom of the Nephites in preparing their places of security.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353406" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>Now the leaders of the Lamanites <span class="page-break" data-page="331"></span>had supposed, because of the greatness of their numbers, yea, they supposed that they should be privileged to come upon them as they had hitherto done; yea, and they had also prepared themselves with shields, and with <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>breastplates</span>; and they had also prepared themselves with garments of skins, yea, very thick garments to cover their nakedness.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353407" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And being thus prepared they supposed that they should easily overpower and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>subject</span> their brethren to the yoke of bondage, or slay and massacre them according to their pleasure.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353408" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>But behold, to their uttermost astonishment, they were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>prepared</span> for them, in a manner which never had been known among the children of Lehi. Now they were prepared for the Lamanites, to battle after the manner of the instructions of Moroni.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353409" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And it came to pass that the Lamanites, or the Amalickiahites, were exceedingly astonished at their manner of preparation for war.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353410" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>Now, if king Amalickiah had come down out of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>land of Nephi</span>, at the head of his army, perhaps he would have caused the Lamanites to have attacked the Nephites at the city of Ammonihah; for behold, he did care not for the blood of his people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353411" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>But behold, Amalickiah did not come down himself to battle. And behold, his chief captains durst not attack the Nephites at the city of Ammonihah, for Moroni had altered the management of affairs among the Nephites, insomuch that the Lamanites were disappointed in their places of retreat and they could not come upon them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353412" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>Therefore they retreated into the wilderness, and took their camp and marched towards the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Noah</span>, supposing that to be the next best place for them to come against the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353413" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>For they knew not that Moroni had fortified, or had built <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>forts</span> of security, for every city in all the land round about; therefore, they marched forward to the land of Noah with a firm determination; yea, their chief captains came forward and took an <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>oath</span> that they would destroy the people of that city.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353414" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>But behold, to their astonishment, the city of Noah, which had hitherto been a weak place, had now, by the means of Moroni, become strong, yea, even to exceed the strength of the city Ammonihah.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353415" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And now, behold, this was wisdom in Moroni; for he had supposed that they would be frightened at the city Ammonihah; and as the city of Noah had hitherto been the weakest part of the land, therefore they would march thither to battle; and thus it was according to his desires.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353416" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And behold, Moroni had appointed Lehi to be chief captain over the men of that city; and it was that <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>same</span> Lehi who fought with the Lamanites in the valley on the east of the river Sidon.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353417" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>And now behold it came to pass, that when the Lamanites had found that Lehi commanded the city they were again disappointed, for they feared Lehi exceedingly; nevertheless their chief captains had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>sworn</span> with an oath to attack the city; therefore, they brought up their armies.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353418" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>Now behold, the Lamanites could not get into their forts of security by any other way save by the entrance, because of the highness of the bank which had been thrown up, and the depth of the <span class="page-break" data-page="332"></span>ditch which had been dug round about, save it were by the entrance.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353419" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>And thus were the Nephites prepared to destroy all such as should attempt to climb up to enter the fort by any other way, by casting over stones and arrows at them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353420" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>Thus they were prepared, yea, a body of their strongest men, with their swords and their slings, to smite down all who should attempt to come into their place of security by the place of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>entrance</span>; and thus were they prepared to defend themselves against the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353421" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And it came to pass that the captains of the Lamanites brought up their armies before the place of entrance, and began to contend with the Nephites, to get into their place of security; but behold, they were driven back from time to time, insomuch that they were slain with an immense slaughter.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353422" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>Now when they found that they could not obtain power over the Nephites by the pass, they began to dig down their banks of earth that they might obtain a pass to their armies, that they might have an equal chance to fight; but behold, in these attempts they were swept off by the stones and arrows which were thrown at them; and instead of filling up their ditches by pulling down the banks of earth, they were filled up in a measure with their dead and wounded bodies.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353423" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>Thus the Nephites had all power over their enemies; and thus the Lamanites did attempt to destroy the Nephites until their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>chief</span> captains were all slain; yea, and more than a thousand of the Lamanites were slain; while, on the other hand, there was not a single soul of the Nephites which was slain.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353424" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>There were about fifty who were wounded, who had been exposed to the arrows of the Lamanites through the pass, but they were shielded by their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>shields</span>, and their breastplates, and their head-plates, insomuch that their wounds were upon their legs, many of which were very severe.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353425" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>And it came to pass, that when the Lamanites saw that their chief captains were all slain they fled into the wilderness. And it came to pass that they returned to the land of Nephi, to inform their king, Amalickiah, who was a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Nephite</span> by birth, concerning their great <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>loss</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353426" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>And it came to pass that he was exceedingly angry with his people, because he had not obtained his desire over the Nephites; he had not subjected them to the yoke of bondage.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353427" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>Yea, he was exceedingly wroth, and he did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>curse</span> God, and also Moroni, swearing with an <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>oath</span> that he would drink his blood; and this because Moroni had kept the commandments of God in preparing for the safety of his people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353428" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>And it came to pass, that on the other hand, the people of Nephi did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note28a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>thank</span> the Lord their God, because of his matchless power in delivering them from the hands of their enemies.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353429" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>And thus ended the nineteenth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353430" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>Yea, and there was continual peace among them, and exceedingly great prosperity in the church because of their heed and diligence which they gave unto the word of God, which was declared unto them by Helaman, and Shiblon, and Corianton, and Ammon and his brethren, yea, and by all those who had been ordained by the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note30a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>holy order</span> of God, being baptized unto repentance, and sent forth to preach among the people.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 50	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128353473" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/50" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 50</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="333"></span>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128353497" id="title_number1">Chapter 50</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128353499" id="study_summary1">Moroni fortifies the lands of the Nephites—They build many new cities—Wars and destructions befell the Nephites in the days of their wickedness and abominations—Morianton and his dissenters are defeated by Teancum—Nephihah dies, and his son Pahoran fills the judgment seat. About 72–67 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353501" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now it came to pass that Moroni did not stop making preparations for war, or to defend his people against the Lamanites; for he caused that his armies should commence in the commencement of the twentieth year of the reign of the judges, that they should commence in digging up <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>heaps</span> of earth round about all the cities, throughout all the land which was possessed by the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353503" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And upon the top of these ridges of earth he caused that there should be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>timbers</span>, yea, works of timbers built up to the height of a man, round about the cities.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353505" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And he caused that upon those works of timbers there should be a frame of pickets built upon the timbers round about; and they were strong and high.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353507" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And he caused towers to be erected that overlooked those works of pickets, and he caused places of security to be built upon those <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>towers</span>, that the stones and the arrows of the Lamanites could not hurt them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353508" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And they were prepared that they could cast stones from the top thereof, according to their pleasure and their strength, and slay him who should attempt to approach near the walls of the city.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353509" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>Thus Moroni did prepare strongholds against the coming of their enemies, round about every city in all the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353510" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And it came to pass that Moroni caused that his armies should go forth into the east wilderness; yea, and they went forth and drove all the Lamanites who were in the east wilderness into their own lands, which were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>south</span> of the land of Zarahemla.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353511" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Nephi</span> did run in a straight course from the east sea to the west.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353512" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And it came to pass that when Moroni had driven all the Lamanites out of the east wilderness, which was north of the lands of their own possessions, he caused that the inhabitants who were in the land of Zarahemla and in the land round about should go forth into the east wilderness, even to the borders by the seashore, and possess the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353513" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And he also placed armies on the south, in the borders of their possessions, and caused them to erect <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>fortifications</span> that they might secure their armies and their people from the hands of their enemies.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353514" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And thus he cut off all the strongholds of the Lamanites in the east wilderness, yea, and also on the west, fortifying the line between the Nephites and the Lamanites, between the land of Zarahemla and the land of Nephi, from the west sea, running by the head of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>river Sidon</span>—the Nephites possessing all the land <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>northward</span>, yea, even all the land which was northward of the land Bountiful, according to their pleasure.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353515" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>Thus Moroni, with his armies, which did increase daily because of the assurance of protection which his works did bring forth unto them, did seek to cut off the strength and the power of the Lamanites from off the lands of their possessions, that they should have no power upon the lands of their possession.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353516" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And it came to pass that the Nephites began the foundation of a <span class="page-break" data-page="334"></span>city, and they called the name of the city <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Moroni</span>; and it was by the east sea; and it was on the south by the line of the possessions of the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353517" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And they also began a foundation for a city between the city of Moroni and the city of Aaron, joining the borders of Aaron and Moroni; and they called the name of the city, or the land, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Nephihah</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353518" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And they also began in that same year to build many cities on the north, one in a particular manner which they called <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Lehi</span>, which was in the north by the borders of the seashore.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353519" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And thus ended the twentieth year.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353520" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>And in these prosperous circumstances were the people of Nephi in the commencement of the twenty and first year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353521" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And they did prosper <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note18a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>exceedingly</span>, and they became exceedingly rich; yea, and they did multiply and wax strong in the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353522" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>And thus we see how merciful and just are all the dealings of the Lord, to the fulfilling of all his words unto the children of men; yea, we can behold that his words are verified, even at this time, which he spake unto Lehi, saying:</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353523" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>Blessed art thou and thy children; and they shall be blessed, inasmuch as they shall keep my <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>commandments</span> they shall prosper in the land. But remember, inasmuch as they will not keep my commandments they shall be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>cut off</span> from the presence of the Lord.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353524" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And we see that these promises have been verified to the people of Nephi; for it has been their quarrelings and their contentions, yea, their murderings, and their plunderings, their idolatry, their whoredoms, and their abominations, which were among themselves, which <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>brought upon</span> them their wars and their destructions.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353525" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>And those who were faithful in keeping the commandments of the Lord were delivered at all times, whilst thousands of their wicked brethren have been consigned to bondage, or to perish by the sword, or to dwindle in unbelief, and mingle with the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353526" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>But behold there never was a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>happier</span> time among the people of Nephi, since the days of Nephi, than in the days of Moroni, yea, even at this time, in the twenty and first year of the reign of the judges.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353527" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>And it came to pass that the twenty and second year of the reign of the judges also ended in peace; yea, and also the twenty and third year.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353528" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>And it came to pass that in the commencement of the twenty and fourth year of the reign of the judges, there would also have been peace among the people of Nephi had it not been for a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>contention</span> which took place among them concerning the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Lehi</span>, and the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>Morianton</span>, which joined upon the borders of Lehi; both of which were on the borders by the seashore.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353529" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>For behold, the people who possessed the land of Morianton did claim a part of the land of Lehi; therefore there began to be a warm <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>contention</span> between them, insomuch that the people of Morianton took up arms against their brethren, and they were determined by the sword to slay them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353530" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>But behold, the people who possessed the land of Lehi fled to the camp of Moroni, and appealed unto <span class="page-break" data-page="335"></span>him for assistance; for behold they were not in the wrong.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353531" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>And it came to pass that when the people of Morianton, who were led by a man whose name was Morianton, found that the people of Lehi had fled to the camp of Moroni, they were exceedingly fearful lest the army of Moroni should come upon them and destroy them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353532" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>Therefore, Morianton put it into their hearts that they should flee to the land which was northward, which was covered with <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note29a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>large</span> bodies of water, and take possession of the land which was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note29b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>northward</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353533" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>And behold, they would have carried this plan into effect, (which would have been a cause to have been lamented) but behold, Morianton being a man of much passion, therefore he was angry with one of his maid servants, and he fell upon her and beat her much.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353534" id="p31"><span class="verse-number">31 </span>And it came to pass that she fled, and came over to the camp of Moroni, and told Moroni all things concerning the matter, and also concerning their intentions to flee into the land northward.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353535" id="p32"><span class="verse-number">32 </span>Now behold, the people who were in the land Bountiful, or rather Moroni, feared that they would hearken to the words of Morianton and unite with his people, and thus he would obtain possession of those parts of the land, which would lay a foundation for serious consequences among the people of Nephi, yea, which <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note32a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>consequences</span> would lead to the overthrow of their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note32b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>liberty</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353536" id="p33"><span class="verse-number">33 </span>Therefore Moroni sent an army, with their camp, to head the people of Morianton, to stop their flight into the land northward.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353537" id="p34"><span class="verse-number">34 </span>And it came to pass that they did not <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note34a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>head</span> them until they had come to the borders of the land <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note34b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Desolation</span>; and there they did head them, by the narrow pass which led by the sea into the land northward, yea, by the sea, on the west and on the east.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353538" id="p35"><span class="verse-number">35 </span>And it came to pass that the army which was sent by Moroni, which was led by a man whose name was Teancum, did meet the people of Morianton; and so stubborn were the people of Morianton, (being inspired by his wickedness and his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note35a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>flattering</span> words) that a battle commenced between them, in the which Teancum did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note35b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>slay</span> Morianton and defeat his army, and took them prisoners, and returned to the camp of Moroni. And thus ended the twenty and fourth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353539" id="p36"><span class="verse-number">36 </span>And thus were the people of Morianton brought back. And upon their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note36a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>covenanting</span> to keep the peace they were restored to the land of Morianton, and a union took place between them and the people of Lehi; and they were also restored to their lands.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353540" id="p37"><span class="verse-number">37 </span>And it came to pass that in the same year that the people of Nephi had peace restored unto them, that Nephihah, the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note37a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>second</span> chief judge, died, having filled the judgment-seat with <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note37b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>perfect</span> uprightness before God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353541" id="p38"><span class="verse-number">38 </span>Nevertheless, he had refused Alma to take possession of those <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note38a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>records</span> and those things which were esteemed by Alma and his fathers to be most sacred; therefore Alma had conferred <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note38b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>them</span> upon his son, Helaman.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353542" id="p39"><span class="verse-number">39 </span>Behold, it came to pass that the son of Nephihah was appointed to fill the judgment-seat, in the stead of his father; yea, he was appointed <span class="page-break" data-page="336"></span>chief judge and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note39a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>governor</span> over the people, with an <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note39b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>oath</span> and sacred ordinance to judge righteously, and to keep the peace and the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note39c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>freedom</span> of the people, and to grant unto them their sacred privileges to worship the Lord their God, yea, to support and maintain the cause of God all his days, and to bring the wicked to justice according to their crime.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353543" id="p40"><span class="verse-number">40 </span>Now behold, his name was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note40a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Pahoran</span>. And Pahoran did fill the seat of his father, and did commence his reign in the end of the twenty and fourth year, over the people of Nephi.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 51	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128352765" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/51" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 51</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128352766" id="title_number1">Chapter 51</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128352767" id="study_summary1">The king-men seek to change the law and set up a king—Pahoran and the freemen are supported by the voice of the people—Moroni compels the king-men to defend their country or be put to death—Amalickiah and the Lamanites capture many fortified cities—Teancum repels the Lamanite invasion and slays Amalickiah in his tent. About 67–66 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352768" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now it came to pass in the commencement of the twenty and fifth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi, they having established peace between the people of Lehi and the people of Morianton concerning their lands, and having commenced the twenty and fifth year in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>peace</span>;</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352769" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>Nevertheless, they did not long maintain an entire peace in the land, for there began to be a contention among the people concerning the chief judge Pahoran; for behold, there were a part of the people who desired that a few particular points of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>law</span> should be altered.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352770" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>But behold, Pahoran would not alter nor suffer the law to be altered; therefore, he did not hearken to those who had sent in their voices with their petitions concerning the altering of the law.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352771" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>Therefore, those who were desirous that the law should be altered were angry with him, and desired that he should no longer be chief judge over the land; therefore there arose a warm <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>dispute</span> concerning the matter, but not unto bloodshed.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352772" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And it came to pass that those who were desirous that Pahoran should be dethroned from the judgment-seat were called <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>king-men</span>, for they were desirous that the law should be altered in a manner to overthrow the free government and to establish a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>king</span> over the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352773" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And those who were desirous that Pahoran should remain chief judge over the land took upon them the name of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>freemen</span>; and thus was the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>division</span> among them, for the freemen had sworn or <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>covenanted</span> to maintain their rights and the privileges of their religion by a free government.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352774" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And it came to pass that this matter of their contention was settled by the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>voice</span> of the people. And it came to pass that the voice of the people came in favor of the freemen, and Pahoran retained the judgment-seat, which caused much rejoicing among the brethren of Pahoran and also many of the people of liberty, who also put the king-men to silence, that they durst not oppose but were obliged to maintain the cause of freedom.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352775" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>Now those who were in favor of kings were those of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>high birth</span>, and they sought to be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>kings</span>; and they were supported by those who sought power and authority over the people.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="337"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352776" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>But behold, this was a critical time for such contentions to be among the people of Nephi; for behold, Amalickiah had again <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>stirred up</span> the hearts of the people of the Lamanites against the people of the Nephites, and he was gathering together soldiers from all parts of his land, and arming them, and preparing for war with all diligence; for he had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>sworn</span> to drink the blood of Moroni.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352777" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>But behold, we shall see that his promise which he made was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>rash</span>; nevertheless, he did prepare himself and his armies to come to battle against the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352778" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>Now his armies were not so great as they had hitherto been, because of the many thousands who had been <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>slain</span> by the hand of the Nephites; but notwithstanding their great loss, Amalickiah had gathered together a wonderfully great army, insomuch that he feared not to come down to the land of Zarahemla.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352779" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>Yea, even Amalickiah did himself come down, at the head of the Lamanites. And it was in the twenty and fifth year of the reign of the judges; and it was at the same time that they had begun to settle the affairs of their contentions concerning the chief judge, Pahoran.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352780" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And it came to pass that when the men who were called king-men had heard that the Lamanites were coming down to battle against them, they were glad in their hearts; and they refused to take up arms, for they were so wroth with the chief judge, and also with the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>people</span> of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>liberty</span>, that they would not take up arms to defend their country.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352781" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And it came to pass that when Moroni saw this, and also saw that the Lamanites were coming into the borders of the land, he was exceedingly wroth because of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>stubbornness</span> of those people whom he had labored with so much diligence to preserve; yea, he was exceedingly wroth; his soul was filled with anger against them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352782" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And it came to pass that he sent a petition, with the voice of the people, unto the governor of the land, desiring that he should read it, and give him (Moroni) power to compel those dissenters to defend their country or to put them to death.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352783" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>For it was his first care to put an end to such contentions and dissensions among the people; for behold, this had been hitherto a cause of all their destruction. And it came to pass that it was granted according to the voice of the people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352784" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>And it came to pass that Moroni commanded that his army should go against those king-men, to pull down their pride and their nobility and level them with the earth, or they should take up arms and support the cause of liberty.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352785" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And it came to pass that the armies did march forth against them; and they did pull down their pride and their nobility, insomuch that as they did lift their weapons of war to fight against the men of Moroni they were hewn down and leveled to the earth.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352786" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>And it came to pass that there were four thousand of those <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>dissenters</span> who were hewn down by the sword; and those of their leaders who were not slain in battle were taken and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>cast</span> into prison, for there was no time for their trials at this period.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352787" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>And the remainder of those dissenters, rather than be smitten down to the earth by the sword, yielded to the standard of liberty, and were compelled to hoist the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>title of liberty</span> upon their towers, and in their cities, and to take up arms in defence of their country.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="338"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352788" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And thus Moroni put an end to those king-men, that there were not any known by the appellation of king-men; and thus he put an end to the stubbornness and the pride of those people who professed the blood of nobility; but they were brought down to humble themselves like unto their brethren, and to fight <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>valiantly</span> for their freedom from bondage.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352789" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>Behold, it came to pass that while Moroni was thus breaking down the wars and contentions among his own people, and subjecting them to peace and civilization, and making regulations to prepare for war against the Lamanites, behold, the Lamanites had come into the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note22a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>land of Moroni</span>, which was in the borders by the seashore.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352790" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>And it came to pass that the Nephites were not sufficiently strong in the city of Moroni; therefore Amalickiah did drive them, slaying many. And it came to pass that Amalickiah took possession of the city, yea, possession of all their fortifications.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352791" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>And those who fled out of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>city of Moroni</span> came to the city of Nephihah; and also the people of the city of Lehi gathered themselves together, and made preparations and were ready to receive the Lamanites to battle.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352792" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>But it came to pass that Amalickiah would not suffer the Lamanites to go against the city of Nephihah to battle, but kept them down by the seashore, leaving men in every city to maintain and defend it.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352793" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>And thus he went on, taking possession of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>many</span> cities, the city of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Nephihah</span>, and the city of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>Lehi</span>, and the city of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>Morianton</span>, and the city of Omner, and the city of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26e"><sup class="marker">e</sup>Gid</span>, and the city of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26f"><sup class="marker">f</sup>Mulek</span>, all of which were on the east borders by the seashore.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352794" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>And thus had the Lamanites obtained, by the cunning of Amalickiah, so many cities, by their numberless hosts, all of which were strongly fortified after the manner of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>fortifications</span> of Moroni; all of which afforded strongholds for the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352795" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>And it came to pass that they marched to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note28a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>borders</span> of the land Bountiful, driving the Nephites before them and slaying many.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352796" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>But it came to pass that they were met by Teancum, who had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note29a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>slain</span> Morianton and had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note29b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>headed</span> his people in his flight.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352797" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>And it came to pass that he headed Amalickiah also, as he was marching forth with his numerous army that he might take possession of the land Bountiful, and also the land <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note30a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>northward</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352798" id="p31"><span class="verse-number">31 </span>But behold he met with a disappointment by being repulsed by Teancum and his men, for they were great warriors; for every man of Teancum did exceed the Lamanites in their strength and in their skill of war, insomuch that they did gain advantage over the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352799" id="p32"><span class="verse-number">32 </span>And it came to pass that they did harass them, insomuch that they did slay them even until it was dark. And it came to pass that Teancum and his men did pitch their tents in the borders of the land Bountiful; and Amalickiah did pitch his tents in the borders on the beach by the seashore, and after this manner were they driven.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352800" id="p33"><span class="verse-number">33 </span>And it came to pass that when the night had come, Teancum and his servant stole forth and went out by night, and went into the camp of Amalickiah; and behold, sleep <span class="page-break" data-page="339"></span>had overpowered them because of their much fatigue, which was caused by the labors and heat of the day.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352801" id="p34"><span class="verse-number">34 </span>And it came to pass that Teancum stole privily into the tent of the king, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note34a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>put</span> a javelin to his heart; and he did cause the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note34b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>death</span> of the king immediately that he did not awake his servants.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352802" id="p35"><span class="verse-number">35 </span>And he returned again privily to his own camp, and behold, his men were asleep, and he awoke them and told them all the things that he had done.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352803" id="p36"><span class="verse-number">36 </span>And he caused that his armies should stand in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note36a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>readiness</span>, lest the Lamanites had awakened and should come upon them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128352804" id="p37"><span class="verse-number">37 </span>And thus endeth the twenty and fifth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi; and thus endeth the days of Amalickiah.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 52	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128353600" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/52" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 52</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128353603" id="title_number1">Chapter 52</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128353605" id="study_summary1">Ammoron succeeds Amalickiah as king of the Lamanites—Moroni, Teancum, and Lehi lead the Nephites in a victorious war against the Lamanites—The city of Mulek is retaken, and Jacob the Zoramite is slain. About 66–64 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353607" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now, it came to pass in the twenty and sixth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi, behold, when the Lamanites awoke on the first morning of the first month, behold, they found Amalickiah was dead in his own tent; and they also saw that Teancum was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>ready</span> to give them battle on that day.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353608" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And now, when the Lamanites saw this they were affrighted; and they abandoned their design in marching into the land northward, and retreated with all their army into the city of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Mulek</span>, and sought protection in their fortifications.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353610" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And it came to pass that the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>brother</span> of Amalickiah was appointed king over the people; and his name was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Ammoron</span>; thus king Ammoron, the brother of king Amalickiah, was appointed to reign in his stead.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353612" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And it came to pass that he did command that his people should maintain those cities, which they had taken by the shedding of blood; for they had not taken any cities save they had lost much blood.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353614" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And now, Teancum saw that the Lamanites were determined to maintain those cities which they had taken, and those parts of the land which they had obtained possession of; and also seeing the enormity of their number, Teancum thought it was not expedient that he should attempt to attack them in their forts.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353615" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>But he kept his men round about, as if making preparations for war; yea, and truly he was preparing to defend himself against them, by <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>casting</span> up walls round about and preparing places of resort.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353617" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And it came to pass that he kept thus preparing for war until Moroni had sent a large number of men to strengthen his army.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353619" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And Moroni also sent orders unto him that he should retain all the prisoners who fell into his hands; for as the Lamanites had taken many prisoners, that he should retain all the prisoners of the Lamanites as a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>ransom</span> for those whom the Lamanites had taken.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353621" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And he also sent orders unto him that he should fortify the land <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Bountiful</span>, and secure the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>narrow</span> pass which led into the land <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>northward</span>, lest the Lamanites should obtain that point and should have power to harass them on every side.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="340"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353622" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And Moroni also sent unto him, desiring him that he would be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>faithful</span> in maintaining that quarter of the land, and that he would seek every opportunity to scourge the Lamanites in that quarter, as much as was in his power, that perhaps he might take again by stratagem or some other way those cities which had been taken out of their hands; and that he also would fortify and strengthen the cities round about, which had not fallen into the hands of the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353624" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And he also said unto him, I would come unto you, but behold, the Lamanites are upon us in the borders of the land by the west sea; and behold, I go against them, therefore I cannot come unto you.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353626" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>Now, the king (Ammoron) had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>departed</span> out of the land of Zarahemla, and had made known unto the queen concerning the death of his brother, and had gathered together a large number of men, and had marched forth against the Nephites on the borders by the west sea.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353628" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And thus he was endeavoring to harass the Nephites, and to draw away a part of their forces to that part of the land, while he had commanded those whom he had left to possess the cities which he had taken, that they should also harass the Nephites on the borders by the east sea, and should take possession of their lands as much as it was in their power, according to the power of their armies.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353629" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And thus were the Nephites in those dangerous circumstances in the ending of the twenty and sixth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353631" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>But behold, it came to pass in the twenty and seventh year of the reign of the judges, that Teancum, by the command of Moroni—who had established armies to protect the south and the west borders of the land, and had begun his march towards the land Bountiful, that he might assist Teancum with his men in retaking the cities which they had lost—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353633" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And it came to pass that Teancum had received orders to make an attack upon the city of Mulek, and retake it if it were possible.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353635" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>And it came to pass that Teancum made preparations to make an attack upon the city of Mulek, and march forth with his army against the Lamanites; but he saw that it was impossible that he could overpower them while they were in their fortifications; therefore he abandoned his designs and returned again to the city Bountiful, to wait for the coming of Moroni, that he might receive strength to his army.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353636" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And it came to pass that Moroni did arrive with his army at the land of Bountiful, in the latter end of the twenty and seventh year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353638" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>And in the commencement of the twenty and eighth year, Moroni and Teancum and many of the chief <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>captains</span> held a council of war—what they should do to cause the Lamanites to come out against them to battle; or that they might by some means flatter them out of their strongholds, that they might gain advantage over them and take again the city of Mulek.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353640" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>And it came to pass they sent embassies to the army of the Lamanites, which protected the city of Mulek, to their leader, whose name was Jacob, desiring him that he would come out with his armies to meet them upon the plains between the two cities. But behold, Jacob, who was a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Zoramite</span>, would not come out with his army to meet them upon the plains.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353642" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And it came to pass that Moroni, having no hopes of meeting them upon fair grounds, therefore, he resolved upon a plan that he might <span class="page-break" data-page="341"></span><span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>decoy</span> the Lamanites out of their strongholds.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353643" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>Therefore he caused that Teancum should take a small number of men and march down near the seashore; and Moroni and his army, by night, marched in the wilderness, on the west of the city <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note22a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Mulek</span>; and thus, on the morrow, when the guards of the Lamanites had discovered Teancum, they ran and told it unto Jacob, their leader.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353645" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>And it came to pass that the armies of the Lamanites did march forth against Teancum, supposing by their numbers to overpower Teancum because of the smallness of his numbers. And as Teancum saw the armies of the Lamanites coming out against him he began to retreat down by the seashore, northward.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353647" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>And it came to pass that when the Lamanites saw that he began to flee, they took courage and pursued them with vigor. And while Teancum was thus leading away the Lamanites who were pursuing them in vain, behold, Moroni commanded that a part of his army who were with him should march forth into the city, and take possession of it.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353649" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>And thus they did, and slew all those who had been left to protect the city, yea, all those who would not <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>yield</span> up their weapons of war.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353650" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>And thus Moroni had obtained possession of the city Mulek with a part of his army, while he marched with the remainder to meet the Lamanites when they should return from the pursuit of Teancum.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353652" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>And it came to pass that the Lamanites did pursue Teancum until they came near the city Bountiful, and then they were met by Lehi and a small army, which had been left to protect the city Bountiful.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353654" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>And now behold, when the chief captains of the Lamanites had beheld Lehi with his army coming against them, they fled in much confusion, lest perhaps they should not obtain the city Mulek before Lehi should overtake them; for they were wearied because of their march, and the men of Lehi were fresh.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353656" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>Now the Lamanites did not know that Moroni had been in their rear with his army; and all they feared was Lehi and his men.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353657" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>Now Lehi was not desirous to overtake them till they should meet Moroni and his army.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353659" id="p31"><span class="verse-number">31 </span>And it came to pass that before the Lamanites had retreated far they were surrounded by the Nephites, by the men of Moroni on one hand, and the men of Lehi on the other, all of whom were fresh and full of strength; but the Lamanites were wearied because of their long march.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353661" id="p32"><span class="verse-number">32 </span>And Moroni commanded his men that they should fall upon them until they had given up their weapons of war.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353663" id="p33"><span class="verse-number">33 </span>And it came to pass that Jacob, being their leader, being also a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note33a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Zoramite</span>, and having an unconquerable spirit, he led the Lamanites forth to battle with exceeding fury against Moroni.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353664" id="p34"><span class="verse-number">34 </span>Moroni being in their course of march, therefore Jacob was determined to slay them and cut his way through to the city of Mulek. But behold, Moroni and his men were more powerful; therefore they did not give way before the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353666" id="p35"><span class="verse-number">35 </span>And it came to pass that they fought on both hands with exceeding fury; and there were many slain on both sides; yea, and Moroni was wounded and Jacob was killed.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353668" id="p36"><span class="verse-number">36 </span>And Lehi pressed upon their rear with such fury with his strong men, that the Lamanites in the rear delivered up their weapons of war; and the remainder of them, being much confused, knew not whither to go or to strike.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353670" id="p37"><span class="verse-number">37 </span>Now Moroni seeing their confusion, he said unto them: If ye will <span class="page-break" data-page="342"></span>bring forth your weapons of war and deliver them up, behold we will forbear shedding your blood.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353671" id="p38"><span class="verse-number">38 </span>And it came to pass that when the Lamanites had heard these words, their chief captains, all those who were not slain, came forth and threw down their weapons of war <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note38a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>at</span> the feet of Moroni, and also commanded their men that they should do the same.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353673" id="p39"><span class="verse-number">39 </span>But behold, there were many that would not; and those who would not deliver up their swords were taken and bound, and their weapons of war were taken from them, and they were compelled to march with their brethren forth into the land Bountiful.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353675" id="p40"><span class="verse-number">40 </span>And now the number of prisoners who were taken exceeded more than the number of those who had been slain, yea, more than those who had been slain on both sides.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 53	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128353599" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/53" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 53</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128353601" id="title_number1">Chapter 53</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128353602" id="study_summary1">The Lamanite prisoners are used to fortify the city Bountiful—Dissensions among the Nephites give rise to Lamanite victories—Helaman takes command of the two thousand stripling sons of the people of Ammon. About 64–63 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353604" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And it came to pass that they did set guards over the prisoners of the Lamanites, and did compel them to go forth and bury their dead, yea, and also the dead of the Nephites who were slain; and Moroni placed men over them to guard them while they should perform their labors.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353606" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And Moroni went to the city of Mulek with Lehi, and took command of the city and gave it unto Lehi. Now behold, this Lehi was a man who had been with Moroni in the more part of all his battles; and he was a man <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>like</span> unto Moroni, and they rejoiced in each other’s safety; yea, they were beloved by each other, and also beloved by all the people of Nephi.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353609" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And it came to pass that after the Lamanites had finished burying their dead and also the dead of the Nephites, they were marched back into the land Bountiful; and Teancum, by the orders of Moroni, caused that they should commence laboring in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>digging</span> a ditch round about the land, or the city, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Bountiful</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353611" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And he caused that they should build a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>breastwork</span> of timbers upon the inner bank of the ditch; and they cast up dirt out of the ditch against the breastwork of timbers; and thus they did cause the Lamanites to labor until they had encircled the city of Bountiful round about with a strong wall of timbers and earth, to an exceeding height.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353613" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And this city became an exceeding stronghold ever after; and in this city they did guard the prisoners of the Lamanites; yea, even within a wall which they had caused them to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>build</span> with their own hands. Now Moroni was compelled to cause the Lamanites to labor, because it was easy to guard them while at their labor; and he desired all his forces when he should make an attack upon the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353616" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And it came to pass that Moroni had thus gained a victory over one of the greatest of the armies of the Lamanites, and had obtained possession of the city of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Mulek</span>, which was one of the strongest holds of the Lamanites in the land of Nephi; and thus he had also built a stronghold to retain his prisoners.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353618" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And it came to pass that he did no more attempt a battle with the Lamanites in that year, but he did employ his men in preparing for war, yea, and in making fortifications to guard against the Lamanites, yea, and also delivering their women and their children from famine and <span class="page-break" data-page="343"></span>affliction, and providing food for their armies.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353620" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And now it came to pass that the armies of the Lamanites, on the west sea, south, while in the absence of Moroni on account of some intrigue amongst the Nephites, which caused <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>dissensions</span> amongst them, had gained some ground over the Nephites, yea, insomuch that they had obtained possession of a number of their cities in that part of the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353623" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And thus because of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>iniquity</span> amongst themselves, yea, because of dissensions and intrigue among themselves they were placed in the most dangerous circumstances.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353625" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And now behold, I have somewhat to say concerning the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>people</span> of Ammon, who, in the beginning, were Lamanites;
