but by Ammon and his brethren, or rather by the power and word of God, they had been <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>converted</span> unto the Lord; and they had been brought down into the land of Zarahemla, and had ever since been protected by the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353627" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And because of their oath they had been kept from taking up arms against their brethren; for they had taken an oath that they <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>never</span> would shed blood more; and according to their oath they would have perished; yea, they would have suffered themselves to have fallen into the hands of their brethren, had it not been for the pity and the exceeding love which Ammon and his brethren had had for them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353630" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And for this cause they were brought down into the land of Zarahemla; and they ever had been <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>protected</span> by the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353632" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>But it came to pass that when they saw the danger, and the many <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>afflictions</span> and tribulations which the Nephites bore for them, they were moved with compassion and were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>desirous</span> to take up arms in the defence of their country.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353634" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>But behold, as they were about to take their weapons of war, they were overpowered by the persuasions of Helaman and his brethren, for they were about to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>break</span> the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>oath</span> which they had made.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353637" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And Helaman feared lest by so doing they should lose their souls; therefore all those who had entered into this covenant were compelled to behold their brethren wade through their afflictions, in their dangerous circumstances at this time.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353639" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>But behold, it came to pass they had many <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>sons</span>, who had not entered into a covenant that they would not take their weapons of war to defend themselves against their enemies; therefore they did assemble themselves together at this time, as many as were able to take up arms, and they called themselves Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353641" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>And they entered into a covenant to fight for the liberty of the Nephites, yea, to protect the land unto the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>laying</span> down of their lives; yea, even they covenanted that they never would give up their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>liberty</span>, but they would fight in all cases to protect the Nephites and themselves from bondage.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353644" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>Now behold, there were two thousand of those young men, who entered into this covenant and took their weapons of war to defend their country.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353646" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>And now behold, as they never had hitherto been a disadvantage to the Nephites, they became now at this period of time also a great support; for they took their weapons of war, and they would that Helaman should be their leader.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353648" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>And they were all young men, <span class="page-break" data-page="344"></span>and they were exceedingly valiant for <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>courage</span>, and also for strength and activity; but behold, this was not all—they were men who were true at all times in whatsoever thing they were entrusted.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353651" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>Yea, they were men of truth and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>soberness</span>, for they had been taught to keep the commandments of God and to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>walk</span> uprightly before him.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353653" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>And now it came to pass that Helaman did march at the head of his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note22a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>two thousand</span> stripling soldiers, to the support of the people in the borders of the land on the south by the west sea.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353655" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>And thus ended the twenty and eighth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 54	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128353828" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/54" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 54</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128353829" id="title_number1">Chapter 54</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128353830" id="study_summary1">Ammoron and Moroni negotiate for the exchange of prisoners—Moroni demands that the Lamanites withdraw and cease their murderous attacks—Ammoron demands that the Nephites lay down their arms and become subject to the Lamanites. About 63 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353831" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now it came to pass in the commencement of the twenty and ninth year of the judges, that <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Ammoron</span> sent unto Moroni desiring that he would exchange prisoners.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353832" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And it came to pass that Moroni felt to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>rejoice</span> exceedingly at this request, for he desired the provisions which were imparted for the support of the Lamanite prisoners for the support of his own people; and he also desired his own people for the strengthening of his army.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353833" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>Now the Lamanites had taken many women and children, and there was not a woman nor a child among all the prisoners of Moroni, or the prisoners whom Moroni had taken; therefore Moroni resolved upon a stratagem to obtain as many prisoners of the Nephites from the Lamanites as it were possible.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353834" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>Therefore he wrote an epistle, and sent it by the servant of Ammoron, the same who had brought an epistle to Moroni. Now these are the words which he wrote unto Ammoron, saying:</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353835" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>Behold, Ammoron, I have written unto you somewhat concerning this war which ye have waged against my people, or rather which thy <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>brother</span> hath waged against them, and which ye are still determined to carry on after his death.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353836" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>Behold, I would tell you somewhat concerning the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>justice</span> of God, and the sword of his almighty wrath, which doth hang over you except ye repent and withdraw your armies into your own lands, or the land of your possessions, which is the land of Nephi.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353837" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>Yea, I would tell you these things if ye were capable of hearkening unto them; yea, I would tell you concerning that awful <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>hell</span> that awaits to receive such <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>murderers</span> as thou and thy brother have been, except ye repent and withdraw your murderous purposes, and return with your armies to your own lands.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353838" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>But as ye have once rejected these things, and have fought against the people of the Lord, even so I may expect you will do it again.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353839" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And now behold, we are prepared to receive you; yea, and except you withdraw your purposes, behold, ye will pull down the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>wrath</span> of that God whom you have rejected upon you, even to your utter destruction.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353840" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>But, as the Lord liveth, our armies shall come upon you except ye withdraw, and ye shall soon be visited with <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>death</span>, for we will retain our cities and our lands; yea, <span class="page-break" data-page="345"></span>and we will maintain our religion and the cause of our God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353841" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>But behold, it supposeth me that I talk to you concerning these things in vain; or it supposeth me that thou art a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>child</span> of hell; therefore I will close my epistle by telling you that I will not exchange prisoners, save it be on conditions that ye will deliver up a man and his wife and his children, for one prisoner; if this be the case that ye will do it, I will exchange.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353842" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And behold, if ye do not this, I will come against you with my armies; yea, even I will arm my women and my children, and I will come against you, and I will follow you even into your own land, which is the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>our</span> first inheritance; yea, and it shall be blood for blood, yea, life for life; and I will give you battle even until you are destroyed from off the face of the earth.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353843" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>Behold, I am in my anger, and also my people; ye have sought to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>murder</span> us, and we have only sought to defend ourselves. But behold, if ye seek to destroy us more we will seek to destroy you; yea, and we will seek our land, the land of our first inheritance.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353844" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>Now I close my epistle. I am Moroni; I am a leader of the people of the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353845" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>Now it came to pass that Ammoron, when he had received this epistle, was angry; and he wrote another epistle unto Moroni, and these are the words which he wrote, saying:</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353846" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>I am Ammoron, the king of the Lamanites; I am the brother of Amalickiah whom ye have <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>murdered</span>. Behold, I will avenge his blood upon you, yea, and I will come upon you with my armies for I fear not your threatenings.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353847" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>For behold, your fathers did wrong their brethren, insomuch that they did rob them of their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>right</span> to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>government</span> when it rightly belonged unto them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353848" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And now behold, if ye will lay down your arms, and subject yourselves to be governed by those to whom the government doth rightly belong, then will I cause that my people shall lay down their weapons and shall be at war no more.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353849" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>Behold, ye have breathed out many threatenings against me and my people; but behold, we fear not your threatenings.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353850" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>Nevertheless, I will grant to exchange prisoners according to your request, gladly, that I may preserve my food for my men of war; and we will wage a war which shall be eternal, either to the subjecting the Nephites to our authority or to their eternal extinction.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353851" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And as concerning that God whom ye say we have rejected, behold, we <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>know not</span> such a being; neither do ye; but if it so be that there is such a being, we know not but that he hath made us as well as you.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353852" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>And if it so be that there is a devil and a hell, behold will he not send you there to dwell with my brother whom ye have murdered, whom ye have hinted that he hath gone to such a place? But behold these things matter not.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353853" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>I am Ammoron, and a descendant of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Zoram</span>, whom your fathers pressed and brought out of Jerusalem.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353854" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>And behold now, I am a bold Lamanite; behold, this war hath been waged to avenge their wrongs, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note24a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>to</span> maintain and to obtain their rights to the government; and I close my epistle to Moroni.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 55	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128353724" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/55" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 55</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128353725" id="title_number1">Chapter 55</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128353726" id="study_summary1">Moroni refuses to exchange prisoners—The Lamanite guards are enticed <span class="page-break" data-page="346"></span>to become drunk, and the Nephite prisoners are freed—The city of Gid is taken without bloodshed. About 63–62 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353727" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>Now it came to pass that when Moroni had received this epistle he was more angry, because he knew that Ammoron had a perfect knowledge of his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>fraud</span>; yea, he knew that Ammoron knew that it was not a just cause that had caused him to wage a war against the people of Nephi.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353728" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And he said: Behold, I will not exchange prisoners with Ammoron save he will withdraw his <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>purpose</span>, as I have stated in my epistle; for I will not grant unto him that he shall have any more power than what he hath got.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353729" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>Behold, I know the place where the Lamanites do guard my people whom they have taken prisoners; and as Ammoron would not grant unto me mine epistle, behold, I will give unto him according to my words; yea, I will seek death among them until they shall sue for peace.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353730" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And now it came to pass that when Moroni had said these words, he caused that a search should be made among his men, that perhaps he might find a man who was a descendant of Laman among them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353731" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And it came to pass that they found one, whose name was Laman; and he was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>one</span> of the servants of the king who was murdered by Amalickiah.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353732" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>Now Moroni caused that Laman and a small number of his men should go forth unto the guards who were over the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353733" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>Now the Nephites were guarded in the city of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Gid</span>; therefore Moroni appointed Laman and caused that a small number of men should go with him.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353734" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And when it was evening Laman went to the guards who were over the Nephites, and behold, they saw him coming and they hailed him; but he saith unto them: Fear not; behold, I am a Lamanite. Behold, we have escaped from the Nephites, and they sleep; and behold we have taken of their wine and brought with us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353735" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>Now when the Lamanites heard these words they received him with joy; and they said unto him: Give us of your wine, that we may drink; we are glad that ye have thus taken wine with you for we are weary.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353736" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>But Laman said unto them: Let us keep of our wine till we go against the Nephites to battle. But this saying only made them more desirous to drink of the wine;</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353737" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>For, said they: We are weary, therefore let us take of the wine, and by and by we shall receive wine for our rations, which will strengthen us to go against the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353738" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And Laman said unto them: You may do according to your desires.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353739" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And it came to pass that they did take of the wine freely; and it was pleasant to their taste, therefore they took of it more freely; and it was strong, having been prepared in its <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>strength</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353740" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And it came to pass they did drink and were merry, and by and by they were all <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>drunken</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353741" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And now when Laman and his men saw that they were all drunken, and were in a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>deep sleep</span>, they returned to Moroni and told him all the things that had happened.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353742" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And now this was according to the design of Moroni. And Moroni had prepared his men with weapons of war; and he went to the city Gid, while the Lamanites were in a deep sleep and drunken, and cast in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>weapons</span> of war unto the prisoners, insomuch that they were all armed;</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353743" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>Yea, even to their women, and all those of their children, as many as were able to use a weapon of war, <span class="page-break" data-page="347"></span>when Moroni had armed all those prisoners; and all those things were done in a profound silence.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353744" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>But had they awakened the Lamanites, behold they were drunken and the Nephites could have slain them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353745" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>But behold, this was not the desire of Moroni; he did not <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>delight</span> in murder or bloodshed, but he delighted in the saving of his people from destruction; and for this cause he might not bring upon him injustice, he would not fall upon the Lamanites and destroy them in their drunkenness.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353746" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>But he had obtained his desires; for he had armed those prisoners of the Nephites who were within the wall of the city, and had given them power to gain possession of those parts which were within the walls.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353747" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And then he caused the men who were with him to withdraw a pace from them, and surround the armies of the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353748" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>Now behold this was done in the night-time, so that when the Lamanites awoke in the morning they beheld that they were surrounded by the Nephites without, and that their prisoners were armed within.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353749" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>And thus they saw that the Nephites had power over them; and in these circumstances they found that it was not expedient that they should fight with the Nephites; therefore their chief <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>captains</span> demanded their weapons of war, and they brought them forth and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>cast</span> them at the feet of the Nephites, pleading for mercy.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353750" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>Now behold, this was the desire of Moroni. He took them prisoners of war, and took possession of the city, and caused that all the prisoners should be liberated, who were Nephites; and they did join the army of Moroni, and were a great strength to his army.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353751" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>And it came to pass that he did cause the Lamanites, whom he had taken prisoners, that they should commence a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>labor</span> in strengthening the fortifications round about the city Gid.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353752" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>And it came to pass that when he had fortified the city Gid, according to his desires, he caused that his prisoners should be taken to the city Bountiful; and he also guarded that city with an exceedingly strong force.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353753" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>And it came to pass that they did, notwithstanding all the intrigues of the Lamanites, keep and protect all the prisoners whom they had taken, and also maintain all the ground and the advantage which they had retaken.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353754" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>And it came to pass that the Nephites began <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note28a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>again</span> to be victorious, and to reclaim their rights and their privileges.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353755" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>Many times did the Lamanites attempt to encircle them about by night, but in these attempts they did lose many prisoners.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353756" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>And many times did they attempt to administer of their wine to the Nephites, that they might destroy them with poison or with drunkenness.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353757" id="p31"><span class="verse-number">31 </span>But behold, the Nephites were not slow to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note31a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>remember</span> the Lord their God in this their time of affliction. They could not be taken in their snares; yea, they would not partake of their wine, save they had first given to some of the Lamanite prisoners.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353758" id="p32"><span class="verse-number">32 </span>And they were thus cautious that no poison should be administered among them; for if their wine would poison a Lamanite it would also poison a Nephite; and thus they did try all their liquors.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353759" id="p33"><span class="verse-number">33 </span>And now it came to pass that it was expedient for Moroni to make preparations to attack the city <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note33a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Morianton</span>; for behold, the Lamanites <span class="page-break" data-page="348"></span>had, by their labors, fortified the city Morianton until it had become an exceeding stronghold.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353760" id="p34"><span class="verse-number">34 </span>And they were continually bringing new forces into that city, and also new supplies of provisions.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353761" id="p35"><span class="verse-number">35 </span>And thus ended the twenty and ninth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 56	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128353872" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/56" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 56</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128353873" id="title_number1">Chapter 56</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128353874" id="study_summary1">Helaman sends an epistle to Moroni, recounting the state of the war with the Lamanites—Antipus and Helaman gain a great victory over the Lamanites—Helaman’s two thousand stripling sons fight with miraculous power, and none of them are slain. <a class="scripture-ref" href="gospellibrary://content/scriptures/bofm/alma/56?verse=1#p1">Verse 1</a>, about 62 <small>B.C.</small>; <a class="scripture-ref" href="gospellibrary://content/scriptures/bofm/alma/56?verse=2-19#p2">verses 2–19</a>, about 66 <small>B.C.</small>; and <a class="scripture-ref" href="gospellibrary://content/scriptures/bofm/alma/56?verse=20-57#p20">verses 20–57</a>, about 65–64 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353875" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now it came to pass in the commencement of the thirtieth year of the reign of the judges, on the second day in the first month, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Moroni</span> received an <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>epistle</span> from Helaman, stating the affairs of the people in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>that</span> quarter of the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353876" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And these are the words which he wrote, saying: My dearly beloved brother, Moroni, as well in the Lord as in the tribulations of our warfare; behold, my beloved brother, I have somewhat to tell you concerning our warfare in this part of the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353877" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>Behold, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>two thousand</span> of the sons of those men whom Ammon brought down out of the land of Nephi—now ye have known that these were descendants of Laman, who was the eldest son of our father Lehi;</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353878" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>Now I need not rehearse unto you concerning their traditions or their unbelief, for thou knowest concerning all these things—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353879" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>Therefore it sufficeth me that I tell you that two thousand of these young men have taken their weapons of war, and would that I should be their leader; and we have come forth to defend our country.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353880" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And now ye also know concerning the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>covenant</span> which their fathers made, that they would not take up their weapons of war against their brethren to shed blood.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353881" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>But in the twenty and sixth year, when they saw our afflictions and our tribulations for them, they were about to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>break</span> the covenant which they had made and take up their weapons of war in our defence.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353882" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>But I would not suffer them that they should break this <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>covenant</span> which they had made, supposing that God would strengthen us, insomuch that we should not suffer more because of the fulfilling the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>oath</span> which they had taken.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353883" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>But behold, here is one thing in which we may have great joy. For behold, in the twenty and sixth year, I, Helaman, did march at the head of these <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>two thousand</span> young men to the city of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Judea</span>, to assist Antipus, whom ye had appointed a leader over the people of that part of the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353884" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And I did join my two thousand <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>sons</span>, (for they are worthy to be called sons) to the army of Antipus, in which strength Antipus did rejoice exceedingly; for behold, his army had been reduced by the Lamanites because their forces had slain a vast number of our men, for which cause we have to mourn.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353885" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>Nevertheless, we may console ourselves in this point, that they have died in the cause of their country and of their God, yea, and they are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>happy</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353886" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And the Lamanites had also retained many prisoners, all of whom are chief <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>captains</span>, for none other have they spared alive. And we suppose that they are now at this <span class="page-break" data-page="349"></span>time in the land of Nephi; it is so if they are not slain.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353887" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And now these are the cities of which the Lamanites have obtained possession by the shedding of the blood of so many of our valiant men:</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353888" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>The land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Manti</span>, or the city of Manti, and the city of Zeezrom, and the city of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Cumeni</span>, and the city of Antiparah.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353889" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And these are the cities which they possessed when I arrived at the city of Judea; and I found Antipus and his men toiling with their might to fortify the city.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353890" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>Yea, and they were depressed in body as well as in spirit, for they had fought valiantly by day and toiled by night to maintain their cities; and thus they had suffered great afflictions of every kind.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353891" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>And now they were determined to conquer in this place or die; therefore you may well suppose that this little force which I brought with me, yea, those <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>sons</span> of mine, gave them great hopes and much joy.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353892" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And now it came to pass that when the Lamanites saw that Antipus had received a greater strength to his army, they were compelled by the orders of Ammoron to not come against the city of Judea, or against us, to battle.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353893" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>And thus were we favored of the Lord; for had they come upon us in this our weakness they might have perhaps destroyed our little army; but thus were we preserved.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353894" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>They were commanded by Ammoron to maintain those cities which they had taken. And thus ended the twenty and sixth year. And in the commencement of the twenty and seventh year we had prepared our city and ourselves for defence.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353895" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>Now we were desirous that the Lamanites should come upon us; for we were not desirous to make an attack upon them in their strongholds.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353896" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>And it came to pass that we kept spies out round about, to watch the movements of the Lamanites, that they might not pass us by night nor by day to make an attack upon our other cities which were on the northward.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353897" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>For we knew in those cities they were not sufficiently strong to meet them; therefore we were desirous, if they should pass by us, to fall upon them in their rear, and thus bring them up in the rear at the same time they were met in the front. We supposed that we could overpower them; but behold, we were disappointed in this our desire.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353898" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>They durst not pass by us with their whole army, neither durst they with a part, lest they should not be sufficiently strong and they should fall.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353899" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>Neither durst they march down against the city of Zarahemla; neither durst they cross the head of Sidon, over to the city of Nephihah.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353900" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>And thus, with their forces, they were determined to maintain those cities which they had taken.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353901" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>And now it came to pass in the second month of this year, there was brought unto us many provisions from the fathers of those my two thousand sons.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353902" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>And also there were sent two thousand men unto us from the land of Zarahemla. And thus we were prepared with ten thousand men, and provisions for them, and also for their wives and their children.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353903" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>And the Lamanites, thus seeing our forces increase daily, and provisions arrive for our support, they began to be fearful, and began to sally forth, if it were possible to put an end to our receiving provisions and strength.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353904" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>Now when we saw that the Lamanites began to grow uneasy on this wise, we were desirous to bring a stratagem into effect upon them; therefore Antipus ordered that I should march forth with my <span class="page-break" data-page="350"></span>little sons to a neighboring city, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note30a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>as</span> if we were carrying provisions to a neighboring city.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353905" id="p31"><span class="verse-number">31 </span>And we were to march near the city of Antiparah, as if we were going to the city beyond, in the borders by the seashore.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353906" id="p32"><span class="verse-number">32 </span>And it came to pass that we did march forth, as if with our provisions, to go to that city.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353907" id="p33"><span class="verse-number">33 </span>And it came to pass that Antipus did march forth with a part of his army, leaving the remainder to maintain the city. But he did not march forth until I had gone forth with my little army, and came near the city Antiparah.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353908" id="p34"><span class="verse-number">34 </span>And now, in the city Antiparah were stationed the strongest army of the Lamanites; yea, the most numerous.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353909" id="p35"><span class="verse-number">35 </span>And it came to pass that when they had been informed by their spies, they came forth with their army and marched against us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353910" id="p36"><span class="verse-number">36 </span>And it came to pass that we did flee before them, northward. And thus we did lead away the most powerful army of the Lamanites;</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353911" id="p37"><span class="verse-number">37 </span>Yea, even to a considerable distance, insomuch that when they saw the army of Antipus pursuing them, with their might, they did not turn to the right nor to the left, but pursued their march in a straight course after us; and, as we suppose, it was their intent to slay us before Antipus should overtake them, and this that they might not be surrounded by our people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353912" id="p38"><span class="verse-number">38 </span>And now Antipus, beholding our danger, did speed the march of his army. But behold, it was night; therefore they did not overtake us, neither did Antipus overtake them; therefore we did camp for the night.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353913" id="p39"><span class="verse-number">39 </span>And it came to pass that before the dawn of the morning, behold, the Lamanites were pursuing us. Now we were not sufficiently strong to contend with them; yea, I would not suffer that my little sons should fall into their hands; therefore we did continue our march, and we took our march into the wilderness.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353914" id="p40"><span class="verse-number">40 </span>Now they durst not turn to the right nor to the left lest they should be surrounded; neither would I turn to the right nor to the left lest they should overtake me, and we could not stand against them, but be slain, and they would make their escape; and thus we did flee all that day into the wilderness, even until it was dark.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353915" id="p41"><span class="verse-number">41 </span>And it came to pass that again, when the light of the morning came we saw the Lamanites upon us, and we did flee before them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353916" id="p42"><span class="verse-number">42 </span>But it came to pass that they did not pursue us far before they halted; and it was in the morning of the third day of the seventh month.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353917" id="p43"><span class="verse-number">43 </span>And now, whether they were overtaken by Antipus we knew not, but I said unto my men: Behold, we know not but they have halted for the purpose that we should come against them, that they might catch us in their snare;</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353918" id="p44"><span class="verse-number">44 </span>Therefore what say ye, my sons, will ye go against them to battle?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353919" id="p45"><span class="verse-number">45 </span>And now I say unto you, my beloved brother Moroni, that never had I seen <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note45a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>so great</span> <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note45b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>courage</span>, nay, not amongst all the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353920" id="p46"><span class="verse-number">46 </span>For as I had ever called them my sons (for they were all of them very young) even so they said unto me: Father, behold our God is with us, and he will <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note46a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>not</span> suffer that we should fall; then let us go forth; we would not slay our brethren if they would let us alone; therefore let us go, lest they should overpower the army of Antipus.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353921" id="p47"><span class="verse-number">47 </span>Now they never had fought, yet they did not fear death; and they did think more upon the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note47a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>liberty</span> of their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note47b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>fathers</span> than they did upon their lives; yea, they had <span class="page-break" data-page="351"></span>been taught by their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note47c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>mothers</span>, that if they did not doubt, God would deliver them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353922" id="p48"><span class="verse-number">48 </span>And they rehearsed unto me the words of their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note48a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>mothers</span>, saying: We <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note48b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>do</span> not doubt our mothers knew it.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353923" id="p49"><span class="verse-number">49 </span>And it came to pass that I did return with my two thousand against these Lamanites who had pursued us. And now behold, the armies of Antipus had overtaken them, and a terrible battle had commenced.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353924" id="p50"><span class="verse-number">50 </span>The army of Antipus being weary, because of their long march in so short a space of time, were about to fall into the hands of the Lamanites; and had I not returned with my two thousand they would have obtained their purpose.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353925" id="p51"><span class="verse-number">51 </span>For Antipus had fallen by the sword, and many of his leaders, because of their weariness, which was occasioned by the speed of their march—therefore the men of Antipus, being confused because of the fall of their leaders, began to give way before the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353926" id="p52"><span class="verse-number">52 </span>And it came to pass that the Lamanites took courage, and began to pursue them; and thus were the Lamanites pursuing them with great vigor when <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note52a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Helaman</span> came upon their rear with his two thousand, and began to slay them exceedingly, insomuch that the whole army of the Lamanites halted and turned upon Helaman.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353927" id="p53"><span class="verse-number">53 </span>Now when the people of Antipus saw that the Lamanites had turned them about, they gathered together their men and came again upon the rear of the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353928" id="p54"><span class="verse-number">54 </span>And now it came to pass that we, the people of Nephi, the people of Antipus, and I with my two thousand, did surround the Lamanites, and did slay them; yea, insomuch that they were compelled to deliver up their weapons of war and also themselves as prisoners of war.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353929" id="p55"><span class="verse-number">55 </span>And now it came to pass that when they had surrendered themselves up unto us, behold, I numbered those young men who had fought with me, fearing lest there were many of them slain.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353930" id="p56"><span class="verse-number">56 </span>But behold, to my great joy, there had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note56a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>not</span> one soul of them fallen to the earth; yea, and they had fought as if with the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note56b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>strength</span> of God; yea, never were men known to have fought with such miraculous strength; and with such mighty power did they fall upon the Lamanites, that they did frighten them; and for this cause did the Lamanites deliver themselves up as prisoners of war.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353931" id="p57"><span class="verse-number">57 </span>And as we had no place for our prisoners, that we could guard them to keep them from the armies of the Lamanites, therefore we sent them to the land of Zarahemla, and a part of those men who were not slain of Antipus, with them; and the remainder I took and joined them to my stripling <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note57a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Ammonites</span>, and took our march back to the city of Judea.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 57	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128353777" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/57" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 57</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128353778" id="title_number1">Chapter 57</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128353779" id="study_summary1">Helaman recounts the taking of Antiparah and the surrender and later the defense of Cumeni—His Ammonite striplings fight valiantly; all are wounded, but none are slain—Gid reports the slaying and the escape of the Lamanite prisoners. About 63 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353780" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now it came to pass that I received an epistle from Ammoron, the king, stating that if I would deliver up those prisoners of war whom we had taken that he would deliver up the city of Antiparah unto us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353781" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>But I sent an epistle unto the king, that we were sure our forces were sufficient to take the city of <span class="page-break" data-page="352"></span>Antiparah by our force; and by delivering up the prisoners for that city we should suppose ourselves unwise, and that we would only deliver up our prisoners on exchange.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353782" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And Ammoron refused mine epistle, for he would not exchange prisoners; therefore we began to make preparations to go against the city of Antiparah.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353783" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>But the people of Antiparah did leave the city, and fled to their other cities, which they had possession of, to fortify them; and thus the city of Antiparah fell into our hands.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353784" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And thus ended the twenty and eighth year of the reign of the judges.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353785" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And it came to pass that in the commencement of the twenty and ninth year, we received a supply of provisions, and also an addition to our army, from the land of Zarahemla, and from the land round about, to the number of six thousand men, besides sixty of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>sons</span> of the Ammonites who had come to join their brethren, my little band of two thousand. And now behold, we were strong, yea, and we had also plenty of provisions brought unto us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353786" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And it came to pass that it was our desire to wage a battle with the army which was placed to protect the city <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Cumeni</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353787" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And now behold, I will show unto you that we soon accomplished our desire; yea, with our strong force, or with a part of our strong force, we did surround, by night, the city Cumeni, a little before they were to receive a supply of provisions.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353788" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And it came to pass that we did camp round about the city for many nights; but we did sleep upon our swords, and keep guards, that the Lamanites could not come upon us by night and slay us, which they attempted many times; but as many times as they attempted this their blood was spilt.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353789" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>At length their provisions did arrive, and they were about to enter the city by night. And we, instead of being Lamanites, were Nephites; therefore, we did take them and their provisions.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353790" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And notwithstanding the Lamanites being cut off from their support after this manner, they were still determined to maintain the city; therefore it became expedient that we should take those provisions and send them to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Judea</span>, and our prisoners to the land of Zarahemla.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353791" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And it came to pass that not many days had passed away before the Lamanites began to lose all hopes of succor; therefore they yielded up the city unto our hands; and thus we had accomplished our designs in obtaining the city Cumeni.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353792" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>But it came to pass that our prisoners were so numerous that, notwithstanding the enormity of our numbers, we were obliged to employ all our force to keep them, or to put them to death.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353793" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>For behold, they would break out in great numbers, and would fight with stones, and with clubs, or whatsoever thing they could get into their hands, insomuch that we did slay upwards of two thousand of them after they had surrendered themselves prisoners of war.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353794" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>Therefore it became expedient for us, that we should put an end to their lives, or guard them, sword in hand, down to the land of Zarahemla; and also our provisions were not any more than sufficient for our own people, notwithstanding that which we had taken from the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353795" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And now, in those critical circumstances, it became a very serious matter to determine concerning these prisoners of war; nevertheless, we did resolve to send them down to the land of Zarahemla; therefore we selected a part of our men, and gave them charge over our prisoners to go down to the land of Zarahemla.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="353"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353796" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>But it came to pass that on the morrow they did return. And now behold, we did not <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>inquire</span> of them concerning the prisoners; for behold, the Lamanites were upon us, and they returned in season to save us from falling into their hands. For behold, Ammoron had sent to their support a new supply of provisions and also a numerous army of men.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353797" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And it came to pass that those men whom we sent with the prisoners did arrive in season to check them, as they were about to overpower us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353798" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>But behold, my little band of two thousand and sixty fought most desperately; yea, they were firm before the Lamanites, and did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>administer</span> death unto all those who opposed them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353799" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>And as the remainder of our army were about to give way before the Lamanites, behold, those two thousand and sixty were firm and undaunted.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353800" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>Yea, and they did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>obey</span> and observe to perform every word of command with exactness; yea, and even according to their faith it was done unto them; and I did remember the words which they said unto me that their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>mothers</span> had taught them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353801" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>And now behold, it was these my sons, and those men who had been selected to convey the prisoners, to whom we owe this great victory; for it was they who did beat the Lamanites; therefore they were driven back to the city of Manti.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353802" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>And we retained our city Cumeni, and were not all destroyed by the sword; nevertheless, we had suffered great loss.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353803" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>And it came to pass that after the Lamanites had fled, I immediately gave orders that my men who had been wounded should be taken from among the dead, and caused that their wounds should be dressed.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353804" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>And it came to pass that there were two hundred, out of my two thousand and sixty, who had fainted because of the loss of blood; nevertheless, according to the goodness of God, and to our great astonishment, and also the joy of our whole army, there was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>not</span> one soul of them who did perish; yea, and neither was there one soul among them who had not received many wounds.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353805" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>And now, their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>preservation</span> was astonishing to our whole army, yea, that they should be spared while there was a thousand of our brethren who were slain. And we do justly ascribe it to the miraculous <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>power</span> of God, because of their exceeding <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>faith</span> in that which they had been taught to believe—that there was a just God, and whosoever did not doubt, that they should be preserved by his marvelous power.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353806" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>Now this was the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>faith</span> of these of whom I have spoken; they are young, and their minds are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>firm</span>, and they do put their trust in God continually.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353807" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>And now it came to pass that after we had thus taken care of our wounded men, and had buried our dead and also the dead of the Lamanites, who were many, behold, we did inquire of Gid concerning the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note28a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>prisoners</span> whom they had started to go down to the land of Zarahemla with.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353808" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>Now Gid was the chief captain over the band who was appointed to guard them down to the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353809" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>And now, these are the words which Gid said unto me: Behold, we did start to go down to the land of Zarahemla with our prisoners. And it came to pass that we did meet the spies of our armies, who <span class="page-break" data-page="354"></span>had been sent out to watch the camp of the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353810" id="p31"><span class="verse-number">31 </span>And they cried unto us, saying—Behold, the armies of the Lamanites are marching towards the city of Cumeni; and behold, they will fall upon them, yea, and will destroy our people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353811" id="p32"><span class="verse-number">32 </span>And it came to pass that our prisoners did hear their cries, which caused them to take courage; and they did rise up in rebellion against us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353812" id="p33"><span class="verse-number">33 </span>And it came to pass because of their rebellion we did cause that our swords should come upon them. And it came to pass that they did in a body run upon our swords, in the which, the greater number of them were slain; and the remainder of them broke through and fled from us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353813" id="p34"><span class="verse-number">34 </span>And behold, when they had fled and we could not overtake them, we took our march with speed towards the city Cumeni; and behold, we did arrive in time that we might assist our brethren in preserving the city.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353814" id="p35"><span class="verse-number">35 </span>And behold, we are again delivered out of the hands of our enemies. And blessed is the name of our God; for behold, it is he that has delivered us; yea, that has done this great thing for us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353815" id="p36"><span class="verse-number">36 </span>Now it came to pass that when I, Helaman, had heard these words of Gid, I was filled with exceeding joy because of the goodness of God in preserving us, that we might not all perish; yea, and I trust that the souls of them who have been slain have <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note36a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>entered</span> into the rest of their God.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 58	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128353961" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/58" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 58</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128353962" id="title_number1">Chapter 58</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128353963" id="study_summary1">Helaman, Gid, and Teomner take the city of Manti by a stratagem—The Lamanites withdraw—The sons of the people of Ammon are preserved as they stand fast in defense of their liberty and faith. About 63–62 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353964" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And behold, now it came to pass that our next object was to obtain the city of Manti; but behold, there was no way that we could lead them out of the city by our small bands. For behold, they remembered that which we had hitherto done; therefore we could not <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>decoy</span> them away from their strongholds.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353965" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And they were so much more numerous than was our army that we durst not go forth and attack them in their strongholds.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353966" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>Yea, and it became expedient that we should employ our men to the maintaining those parts of the land which we had regained of our possessions; therefore it became expedient that we should wait, that we might receive more strength from the land of Zarahemla and also a new supply of provisions.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353967" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And it came to pass that I thus did send an embassy to the governor of our land, to acquaint him concerning the affairs of our people. And it came to pass that we did wait to receive provisions and strength from the land of Zarahemla.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353968" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>But behold, this did profit us but little; for the Lamanites were also receiving great strength from day to day, and also many provisions; and thus were our circumstances at this period of time.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353969" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And the Lamanites were sallying forth against us from time to time, resolving by stratagem to destroy us; nevertheless we could not come to battle with them, because of their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>retreats</span> and their strongholds.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353970" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And it came to pass that we did wait in these difficult circumstances for the space of many months, even until we were about to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>perish</span> for the want of food.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353971" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>But it came to pass that we did receive food, which was guarded to us by an army of two thousand men to our assistance; and this is all the assistance which we did receive, to defend ourselves and our country <span class="page-break" data-page="355"></span>from falling into the hands of our enemies, yea, to contend with an enemy which was innumerable.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353972" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And now the cause of these our embarrassments, or the cause why they did not send more strength unto us, we knew not; therefore we were grieved and also filled with fear, lest by any means the judgments of God should come upon our land, to our overthrow and utter destruction.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353973" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>Therefore we did pour out our souls in prayer to God, that he would strengthen us and deliver us out of the hands of our enemies, yea, and also give us strength that we might retain our cities, and our lands, and our possessions, for the support of our people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353974" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>Yea, and it came to pass that the Lord our God did visit us with assurances that he would deliver us; yea, insomuch that he did speak peace to our souls, and did grant unto us great faith, and did cause us that we should hope for our <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>deliverance</span> in him.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353975" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And we did take courage with our small force which we had received, and were fixed with a determination to conquer our enemies, and to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>maintain</span> our lands, and our possessions, and our wives, and our children, and the cause of our <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>liberty</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353976" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And thus we did go forth with all our might against the Lamanites, who were in the city of Manti; and we did pitch our tents by the wilderness side, which was near to the city.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353977" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And it came to pass that on the morrow, that when the Lamanites saw that we were in the borders by the wilderness which was near the city, that they sent out their spies round about us that they might discover the number and the strength of our army.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353978" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And it came to pass that when they saw that we were not strong, according to our numbers, and fearing that we should cut them off from their support except they should come out to battle against us and kill us, and also supposing that they could easily destroy us with their numerous hosts, therefore they began to make preparations to come out against us to battle.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353979" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And when we saw that they were making preparations to come out against us, behold, I caused that Gid, with a small number of men, should <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>secrete</span> himself in the wilderness, and also that Teomner and a small number of men should secrete themselves also in the wilderness.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353980" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>Now Gid and his men were on the right and the others on the left; and when they had thus secreted themselves, behold, I remained, with the remainder of my army, in that same place where we had first pitched our tents against the time that the Lamanites should come out to battle.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353981" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And it came to pass that the Lamanites did come out with their numerous army against us. And when they had come and were about to fall upon us with the sword, I caused that my men, those who were with me, should retreat into the wilderness.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353982" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>And it came to pass that the Lamanites did follow after us with great speed, for they were exceedingly desirous to overtake us that they might slay us; therefore they did follow us into the wilderness; and we did pass by in the midst of Gid and Teomner, insomuch that they were not discovered by the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353983" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>And it came to pass that when the Lamanites had passed by, or when the army had passed by, Gid and Teomner did rise up from their secret places, and did cut off the spies of the Lamanites that they should not return to the city.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="356"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353984" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And it came to pass that when they had cut them off, they ran to the city and fell upon the guards who were left to guard the city, insomuch that they did destroy them and did take possession of the city.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353985" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>Now this was done because the Lamanites did suffer their whole army, save a few guards only, to be led away into the wilderness.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353986" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>And it came to pass that Gid and Teomner by this means had obtained possession of their strongholds. And it came to pass that we took our course, after having traveled much in the wilderness towards the land of Zarahemla.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353987" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>And when the Lamanites saw that they were marching towards the land of Zarahemla, they were exceedingly afraid, lest there was a plan laid to lead them on to destruction; therefore they began to retreat into the wilderness again, yea, even back by the same way which they had come.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353988" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>And behold, it was night and they did pitch their tents, for the chief <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>captains</span> of the Lamanites had supposed that the Nephites were weary because of their march; and supposing that they had driven their whole army therefore they took no thought concerning the city of Manti.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353989" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>Now it came to pass that when it was night, I caused that my men should not sleep, but that they should march forward by another way towards the land of Manti.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353990" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>And because of this our march in the night-time, behold, on the morrow we were beyond the Lamanites, insomuch that we did arrive before them at the city of Manti.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353991" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>And thus it came to pass, that by this stratagem we did take possession of the city of Manti without the shedding of blood.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353992" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>And it came to pass that when the armies of the Lamanites did arrive near the city, and saw that we were prepared to meet them, they were astonished exceedingly and struck with great fear, insomuch that they did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note29a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>flee</span> into the wilderness.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353993" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>Yea, and it came to pass that the armies of the Lamanites did flee out of all this quarter of the land. But behold, they have carried with them many women and children out of the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353994" id="p31"><span class="verse-number">31 </span>And <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note31a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>those</span> cities which had been taken by the Lamanites, all of them are at this period of time in our possession; and our fathers and our women and our children are returning to their homes, all save it be those who have been taken prisoners and carried off by the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353995" id="p32"><span class="verse-number">32 </span>But behold, our armies are small to maintain so great a number of cities and so great possessions.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353996" id="p33"><span class="verse-number">33 </span>But behold, we <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note33a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>trust</span> in our God who has given us victory over those lands, insomuch that we have obtained those cities and those lands, which were our own.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353997" id="p34"><span class="verse-number">34 </span>Now we do not know the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note34a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>cause</span> that the government does not grant us more strength; neither do those men who came up unto us know why we have not received greater strength.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353998" id="p35"><span class="verse-number">35 </span>Behold, we do not know but what <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note35a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>ye</span> are unsuccessful, and ye have drawn away the forces into that quarter of the land; if so, we do not desire to murmur.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128353999" id="p36"><span class="verse-number">36 </span>And if it is not so, behold, we fear that there is some <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note36a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>faction</span> in the government, that they do not send more men to our assistance; for we know that they are more numerous than that which they have sent.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354000" id="p37"><span class="verse-number">37 </span>But, behold, it mattereth not—we trust God will <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note37a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>deliver</span> us, notwithstanding the weakness of our armies, yea, and deliver us out of the hands of our enemies.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="357"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354001" id="p38"><span class="verse-number">38 </span>Behold, this is the twenty and ninth year, in the latter end, and we are in the possession of our lands; and the Lamanites have fled to the land of Nephi.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354002" id="p39"><span class="verse-number">39 </span>And those sons of the people of Ammon, of whom I have so highly spoken, are with me in the city of Manti; and the Lord has supported them, yea, and kept them from falling by the sword, insomuch that even <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note39a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>one</span> soul has not been slain.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354003" id="p40"><span class="verse-number">40 </span>But behold, they have received many wounds; nevertheless they <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note40a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>stand fast</span> in that <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note40b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>liberty</span> wherewith God has made them free; and they are strict to remember the Lord their God from day to day; yea, they do observe to keep his statutes, and his judgments, and his commandments continually; and their faith is strong in the prophecies concerning that which is to come.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354004" id="p41"><span class="verse-number">41 </span>And now, my beloved brother, Moroni, may the Lord our God, who has redeemed us and made us free, keep you continually in his presence; yea, and may he favor this people, even that ye may have success in obtaining the possession of all that which the Lamanites have taken from us, which was for our support. And now, behold, I close mine epistle. I am Helaman, the son of Alma.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
