Alma 59	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128354831" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/59" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 59</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128354832" id="title_number1">Chapter 59</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128354833" id="study_summary1">Moroni asks Pahoran to strengthen the forces of Helaman—The Lamanites take the city of Nephihah—Moroni is angry with the government. About 62 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354834" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>Now it came to pass in the thirtieth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi, after Moroni had received and had read Helaman’s <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>epistle</span>, he was exceedingly rejoiced because of the welfare, yea, the exceeding success which Helaman had had, in obtaining <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>those</span> lands which were lost.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354835" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>Yea, and he did make it known unto all his people, in all the land round about in that part where he was, that they might rejoice also.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354836" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And it came to pass that he immediately sent <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>an</span> epistle to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Pahoran</span>, desiring that he should cause men to be gathered together to strengthen Helaman, or the armies of Helaman, insomuch that he might with ease maintain that part of the land which he had been so miraculously prospered in regaining.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354837" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And it came to pass when Moroni had sent this epistle to the land of Zarahemla, he began again to lay a plan that he might obtain the remainder of those possessions and cities which the Lamanites had taken from them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354838" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And it came to pass that while Moroni was thus making preparations to go against the Lamanites to battle, behold, the people of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Nephihah</span>, who were gathered together from the city of Moroni and the city of Lehi and the city of Morianton, were attacked by the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354839" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>Yea, even those who had been <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>compelled</span> to flee from the land of Manti, and from the land round about, had come over and joined the Lamanites in this part of the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354840" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And thus being exceedingly numerous, yea, and receiving strength from day to day, by the command of Ammoron they came forth against the people of Nephihah, and they did begin to slay them with an exceedingly great slaughter.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354841" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And their armies were so numerous that the remainder of the people of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Nephihah</span> were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>obliged</span> to flee before them; and they came even and joined the army of Moroni.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="358"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354842" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And now as Moroni had supposed that there <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>should</span> be men sent to the city of Nephihah, to the assistance of the people to maintain that city, and knowing that it was easier to keep the city from falling into the hands of the Lamanites than to retake it from them, he supposed that they would easily maintain that city.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354843" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>Therefore he retained all his force to maintain those places which he had recovered.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354844" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And now, when Moroni saw that the city of Nephihah was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>lost</span> he was exceedingly sorrowful, and began to doubt, because of the wickedness of the people, whether they should not fall into the hands of their brethren.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354845" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>Now this was the case with all his chief captains. They doubted and marveled also because of the wickedness of the people, and this because of the success of the Lamanites over them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354846" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And it came to pass that Moroni was angry with the government, because of their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>indifference</span> concerning the freedom of their country.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 60	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128354023" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/60" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 60</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128354024" id="title_number1">Chapter 60</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128354025" id="study_summary1">Moroni complains to Pahoran of the government’s neglect of the armies—The Lord suffers the righteous to be slain—The Nephites must use all of their power and means to deliver themselves from their enemies—Moroni threatens to fight against the government unless help is supplied to his armies. About 62 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354026" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And it came to pass that he wrote <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>again</span> to the governor of the land, who was Pahoran, and these are the words which he wrote, saying: Behold, I direct mine epistle to Pahoran, in the city of Zarahemla, who is the chief judge and the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>governor</span> over the land, and also to all those who have been chosen by this people to govern and manage the affairs of this war.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354027" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>For behold, I have somewhat to say unto them by the way of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>condemnation</span>; for behold, ye yourselves know that ye have been appointed to gather together men, and arm them with swords, and with cimeters, and all manner of weapons of war of every kind, and send forth against the Lamanites, in whatsoever parts they should come into our land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354028" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And now behold, I say unto you that myself, and also my men, and also Helaman and his men, have suffered exceedingly great <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>sufferings</span>; yea, even hunger, thirst, and fatigue, and all manner of afflictions of every kind.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354029" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>But behold, were this all we had suffered we would not murmur nor complain.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354030" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>But behold, great has been the slaughter among our people; yea, thousands have fallen by the sword, while it might have otherwise been if ye had rendered unto our armies sufficient strength and succor for them. Yea, great has been your neglect towards us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354031" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And now behold, we desire to know the cause of this exceedingly great neglect; yea, we desire to know the cause of your thoughtless state.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354032" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>Can you think to sit upon your thrones in a state of thoughtless <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>stupor</span>, while your enemies are spreading the work of death around you? Yea, while they are murdering thousands of your brethren—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354033" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>Yea, even they who have looked up to you for protection, yea, have placed you in a situation that ye might have succored them, yea, ye might have sent armies unto them, to have strengthened them, and have saved thousands of them from falling by the sword.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="359"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354034" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>But behold, this is not all—ye have withheld your provisions from them, insomuch that many have fought and bled out their lives because of their great desires which they had for the welfare of this people; yea, and this they have done when they were about to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>perish</span> with hunger, because of your exceedingly great neglect towards them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354035" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And now, my beloved brethren—for ye ought to be beloved; yea, and ye ought to have stirred yourselves more diligently for the welfare and the freedom of this people; but behold, ye have neglected them insomuch that the blood of thousands shall come upon your heads for vengeance; yea, for <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>known</span> unto God were all their cries, and all their sufferings—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354036" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>Behold, could ye suppose that ye could sit upon your thrones, and because of the exceeding goodness of God ye could do nothing and he would deliver you? Behold, if ye have supposed this ye have supposed in vain.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354037" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>Do ye <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>suppose</span> that, because so many of your brethren have been killed it is because of their wickedness? I say unto you, if ye have supposed this ye have supposed in vain; for I say unto you, there are many who have fallen by the sword; and behold it is to your condemnation;</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354038" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>For the Lord suffereth the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>righteous</span> to be slain that his justice and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>judgment</span> may come upon the wicked; therefore ye need not suppose that the righteous are lost because they are slain; but behold, they do enter into the rest of the Lord their God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354039" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And now behold, I say unto you, I fear exceedingly that the judgments of God will come upon this people, because of their exceeding <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>slothfulness</span>, yea, even the slothfulness of our government, and their exceedingly great neglect towards their brethren, yea, towards those who have been slain.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354040" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>For were it not for the wickedness which first commenced at our head, we <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>could</span> have withstood our enemies that they could have gained no power over us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354041" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>Yea, had it not been for the war which broke out <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>among</span> ourselves; yea, were it not for these <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>king-men</span>, who caused so much bloodshed among ourselves; yea, at the time we were contending among ourselves, if we had united our strength as we hitherto have done; yea, had it not been for the desire of power and authority which those king-men had over us; had they been true to the cause of our freedom, and united with us, and gone forth against our enemies, instead of taking up their swords against us, which was the cause of so much bloodshed among ourselves; yea, if we had gone forth against them in the strength of the Lord, we should have dispersed our enemies, for it would have been done, according to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>fulfilling</span> of his word.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354042" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>But behold, now the Lamanites are coming upon us, taking <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>possession</span> of our lands, and they are murdering our people with the sword, yea, our women and our children, and also carrying them away captive, causing them that they should suffer all manner of afflictions, and this because of the great wickedness of those who are seeking for power and authority, yea, even those king-men.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354043" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>But why should I say much concerning this matter? For we know not but what ye yourselves are seeking for authority. We know not but what ye are also <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note18a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>traitors</span> to your country.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="360"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354044" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>Or is it that ye have neglected us because ye are in the heart of our country and ye are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note19a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>surrounded</span> by security, that ye do not cause food to be sent unto us, and also men to strengthen our armies?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354045" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>Have ye forgotten the commandments of the Lord your God? Yea, have ye forgotten the captivity of our fathers? Have ye forgotten the many times we have been delivered out of the hands of our enemies?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354046" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>Or do ye suppose that the Lord <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>will</span> still deliver us, while we sit upon our thrones and do not make use of the means which the Lord has provided for us?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354047" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>Yea, will ye sit in idleness while ye are surrounded with thousands of those, yea, and tens of thousands, who do also sit in idleness, while there are thousands round about in the borders of the land who are falling by the sword, yea, wounded and bleeding?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354048" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>Do ye suppose that God will look upon you as guiltless while ye sit still and behold these things? Behold I say unto you, Nay. Now I would that ye should remember that God has said that the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>inward</span> vessel shall be <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>cleansed</span> first, and then shall the outer vessel be cleansed also.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354049" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>And now, except ye do repent of that which ye have done, and begin to be up and doing, and send forth food and men unto us, and also unto Helaman, that he may support those parts of our country which he has regained, and that we may also recover the remainder of our possessions in these parts, behold it will be expedient that we contend no more with the Lamanites until we have first cleansed our inward vessel, yea, even the great head of our government.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354050" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>And except ye grant mine epistle, and come out and show unto me a true <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note25a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>spirit</span> of freedom, and strive to strengthen and fortify our armies, and grant unto them food for their support, behold I will leave a part of my freemen to maintain this part of our land, and I will leave the strength and the blessings of God upon them, that none other power can operate against them—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354051" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>And this because of their exceeding faith, and their patience in their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>tribulations</span>—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354052" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>And I will come unto you, and if there be any among you that has a desire for freedom, yea, if there be even a spark of freedom remaining, behold I will stir up insurrections among you, even until those who have desires to usurp power and authority shall become extinct.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354053" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>Yea, behold I do not fear your power nor your authority, but it is my <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note28a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>God</span> whom I fear; and it is according to his commandments that I do take my sword to defend the cause of my country, and it is because of your iniquity that we have suffered so much loss.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354054" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>Behold it is time, yea, the time is now at hand, that except ye do bestir yourselves in the defence of your country and your little ones, the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note29a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>sword</span> of justice doth hang over you; yea, and it shall fall upon you and visit you even to your utter destruction.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354055" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>Behold, I wait for assistance from you; and, except ye do administer unto our relief, behold, I come unto you, even in the land of Zarahemla, and smite you with the sword, insomuch that ye can have no more power to impede the progress of this people in the cause of our freedom.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354056" id="p31"><span class="verse-number">31 </span>For behold, the Lord will not suffer that ye shall live and wax strong in your iniquities to destroy his righteous people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354057" id="p32"><span class="verse-number">32 </span>Behold, can you suppose that the Lord will spare you and come <span class="page-break" data-page="361"></span>out in judgment against the Lamanites, when it is the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note32a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>tradition</span> of their fathers that has caused their hatred, yea, and it has been redoubled by those who have dissented from us, while your iniquity is for the cause of your love of glory and the vain things of the world?</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354058" id="p33"><span class="verse-number">33 </span>Ye know that ye do transgress the laws of God, and ye do know that ye do trample them under your feet. Behold, the Lord saith unto me: If those whom ye have appointed your governors do not repent of their sins and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note33a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>iniquities</span>, ye shall <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note33b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>go</span> up to battle against them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354059" id="p34"><span class="verse-number">34 </span>And now behold, I, Moroni, am constrained, according to the covenant which I have made to keep the commandments of my God; therefore I would that ye should adhere to the word of God, and send speedily unto me of your provisions and of your men, and also to Helaman.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354060" id="p35"><span class="verse-number">35 </span>And behold, if ye will not do this I come unto you speedily; for behold, God will not suffer that we should perish with hunger; therefore he will give unto us of your food, even if it must be by the sword. Now see that ye fulfil the word of God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354061" id="p36"><span class="verse-number">36 </span>Behold, I am Moroni, your chief captain. I <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note36a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>seek</span> not for power, but to pull it down. I <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note36b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>seek</span> not for honor of the world, but for the glory of my God, and the freedom and welfare of my country. And thus I close mine epistle.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 61	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128354888" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/61" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 61</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128354889" id="title_number1">Chapter 61</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128354890" id="study_summary1">Pahoran tells Moroni of the insurrection and rebellion against the government—The king-men take Zarahemla and are in league with the Lamanites—Pahoran asks for military aid against the rebels. About 62 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354891" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>Behold, now it came to pass that soon after Moroni had sent his epistle unto the chief governor, he received an epistle from <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Pahoran</span>, the chief governor. And these are the words which he received:</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354892" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>I, Pahoran, who am the chief governor of this land, do send these words unto Moroni, the chief captain over the army. Behold, I say unto you, Moroni, that I do not joy in your great <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>afflictions</span>, yea, it grieves my soul.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354893" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>But behold, there are those who do joy in your afflictions, yea, insomuch that they have risen up in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>rebellion</span> against me, and also those of my people who are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>freemen</span>, yea, and those who have risen up are exceedingly numerous.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354895" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And it is those who have sought to take away the judgment-seat from me that have been the cause of this great iniquity; for they have used great <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>flattery</span>, and they have <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>led away</span> the hearts of many people, which will be the cause of sore affliction among us; they have withheld our provisions, and have daunted our <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>freemen</span> that they have not come unto you.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354896" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And behold, they have driven me out before them, and I have fled to the land of Gideon, with as many men as it were possible that I could get.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354897" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And behold, I have sent a proclamation throughout this part of the land; and behold, they are <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>flocking</span> to us <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>daily</span>, to their arms, in the defence of their country and their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>freedom</span>, and to avenge our <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6d"><sup class="marker">d</sup>wrongs</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354898" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And they have come unto us, insomuch that those who have risen up in rebellion against us are set at defiance, yea, insomuch that they do fear us and durst not come out against us to battle.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="362"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354899" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>They have <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>got</span> possession of the land, or the city, of Zarahemla; they have appointed a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>king</span> over them, and he hath written unto the king of the Lamanites, in the which he hath joined an alliance with him; in the which alliance he hath agreed to maintain the city of Zarahemla, which maintenance he supposeth will enable the Lamanites to conquer the remainder of the land, and he shall be placed king over this people when they shall be conquered <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>under</span> the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354900" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And now, in your epistle you have <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>censured</span> me, but it mattereth not; I am not angry, but do rejoice in the greatness of your heart. I, Pahoran, do not <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>seek</span> for power, save only to retain my judgment-seat that I may preserve the rights and the liberty of my people. My soul standeth fast in that liberty in the which God hath made us <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>free</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354901" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And now, behold, we will resist wickedness even unto bloodshed. We would <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>not</span> shed the blood of the Lamanites if they would stay in their own land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354902" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>We would not shed the blood of our brethren if they would not rise up in rebellion and take the sword against us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354903" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>We would subject ourselves to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>yoke</span> of bondage if it were requisite with the justice of God, or if he should command us so to do.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354904" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>But behold he doth not command us that we shall subject ourselves to our enemies, but that we should put our <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>trust</span> in him, and he will deliver us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354905" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>Therefore, my beloved brother, Moroni, let us resist evil, and whatsoever evil we cannot resist with our <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>words</span>, yea, such as rebellions and dissensions, let us <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>resist</span> them with our swords, that we may retain our freedom, that we may rejoice in the great privilege of our church, and in the cause of our Redeemer and our God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354906" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>Therefore, come unto me speedily with a few of your men, and leave the remainder in the charge of Lehi and Teancum; give unto them power to conduct the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>war</span> in that part of the land, according to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Spirit</span> of God, which is also the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>spirit</span> of freedom which is in them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354907" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>Behold I have sent a few provisions unto them, that they may not perish until ye can come unto me.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354908" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>Gather together whatsoever force ye can upon your march hither, and we will go speedily against those dissenters, in the strength of our God according to the faith which is in us.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354909" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And we will <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note18a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>take</span> possession of the city of Zarahemla, that we may obtain more food to send forth unto Lehi and Teancum; yea, we will go forth against them in the strength of the Lord, and we will put an end to this great iniquity.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354910" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>And now, Moroni, I do joy in receiving your epistle, for I was somewhat worried concerning what we should do, whether it should be just in us to go against our brethren.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354911" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>But ye have said, except they repent the Lord <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note20a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>hath</span> commanded you that ye should go against them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354912" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>See that ye <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>strengthen</span> Lehi and Teancum in the Lord; tell them to fear not, for God will deliver them, yea, and also all those who <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>stand fast</span> in that liberty wherewith God hath made them free. And now I close mine epistle to my beloved brother, Moroni.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 62	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128354087" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/62" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 62</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="363"></span>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128354088" id="title_number1">Chapter 62</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128354089" id="study_summary1">Moroni marches to the aid of Pahoran in the land of Gideon—The king-men who refuse to defend their country are put to death—Pahoran and Moroni retake Nephihah—Many Lamanites join the people of Ammon—Teancum slays Ammoron and is in turn slain—The Lamanites are driven from the land, and peace is established—Helaman returns to the ministry and builds up the Church. About 62–57 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354090" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now it came to pass that when Moroni had received this epistle his heart did take courage, and was filled with exceedingly great joy because of the faithfulness of Pahoran, that he was not also a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>traitor</span> to the freedom and cause of his country.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354091" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>But he did also mourn exceedingly because of the iniquity of those who had driven Pahoran from the judgment-seat, yea, in fine because of those who had rebelled against their country and also their God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354092" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And it came to pass that Moroni took a small number of men, according to the desire of Pahoran, and gave Lehi and Teancum command over the remainder of his army, and took his march towards the land of Gideon.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354093" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And he did raise the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>standard</span> of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>liberty</span> in whatsoever place he did enter, and gained whatsoever force he could in all his march towards the land of Gideon.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354094" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And it came to pass that thousands did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>flock</span> unto his standard, and did take up their swords in the defence of their freedom, that they might not come into bondage.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354914" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And thus, when Moroni had gathered together whatsoever men he could in all his march, he came to the land of Gideon; and uniting his forces with those of Pahoran they became exceedingly strong, even stronger than the men of Pachus, who was the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>king</span> of those dissenters who had driven the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>freemen</span> out of the land of Zarahemla and had taken possession of the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354916" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And it came to pass that Moroni and Pahoran went down with their armies into the land of Zarahemla, and went forth against the city, and did meet the men of Pachus, insomuch that they did come to battle.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354918" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And behold, Pachus was slain and his men were taken prisoners, and Pahoran was restored to his judgment-seat.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354920" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And the men of Pachus received their trial, according to the law, and also those king-men who had been taken and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>cast</span> into prison; and they were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>executed</span> according to the law; yea, those men of Pachus and those <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>king-men</span>, whosoever would not take up arms in the defence of their country, but would fight against it, were put to death.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354922" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And thus it became expedient that this law should be strictly observed for the safety of their country; yea, and whosoever was found denying their freedom was speedily <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>executed</span> according to the law.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354924" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And thus ended the thirtieth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi; Moroni and Pahoran having restored peace to the land of Zarahemla, among their own people, having <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>inflicted</span> death upon all those who were not true to the cause of freedom.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354926" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>And it came to pass in the commencement of the thirty and first year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi, Moroni immediately caused that provisions should be sent, and also an army of six thousand men should be sent unto Helaman, to assist him in preserving that part of the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354928" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And he also caused that an <span class="page-break" data-page="364"></span>army of six thousand men, with a sufficient quantity of food, should be sent to the armies of Lehi and Teancum. And it came to pass that this was done to fortify the land against the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354930" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And it came to pass that Moroni and Pahoran, leaving a large body of men in the land of Zarahemla, took their march with a large body of men towards the land of Nephihah, being determined to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>overthrow</span> the Lamanites in that city.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354932" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And it came to pass that as they were marching towards the land, they took a large body of men of the Lamanites, and slew many of them, and took their provisions and their weapons of war.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354934" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And it came to pass after they had taken them, they caused them to enter into a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>covenant</span> that they would no more take up their weapons of war against the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354936" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>And when they had entered into this covenant they sent them to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>dwell</span> with the people of Ammon, and they were in number about four thousand who had not been slain.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354938" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And it came to pass that when they had sent them away they pursued their march towards the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note18a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Nephihah</span>. And it came to pass that when they had come to the city of Nephihah, they did pitch their tents in the plains of Nephihah, which is near the city of Nephihah.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354940" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>Now Moroni was desirous that the Lamanites should come out to battle against them, upon the plains; but the Lamanites, knowing of their exceedingly great courage, and beholding the greatness of their numbers, therefore they durst not come out against them; therefore they did not come to battle in that day.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354942" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>And when the night came, Moroni went forth in the darkness of the night, and came upon the top of the wall to spy out in what part of the city the Lamanites did camp with their army.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354944" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And it came to pass that they were on the east, by the entrance; and they were all asleep. And now Moroni returned to his army, and caused that they should prepare in haste strong cords and ladders, to be let down from the top of the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note21a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>wall</span> into the inner part of the wall.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354946" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>And it came to pass that Moroni caused that his men should march forth and come upon the top of the wall, and let <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note22a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>themselves</span> down into that part of the city, yea, even on the west, where the Lamanites did not camp with their armies.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354948" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>And it came to pass that they were all let down into the city by night, by the means of their strong cords and their ladders; thus when the morning came they were all within the walls of the city.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354950" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>And now, when the Lamanites awoke and saw that the armies of Moroni were within the walls, they were affrighted exceedingly, insomuch that they did flee out by the pass.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354952" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>And now when Moroni saw that they were fleeing before him, he did cause that his men should march forth against them, and slew many, and surrounded many others, and took them prisoners; and the remainder of them fled into the land of Moroni, which was in the borders by the seashore.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354954" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>Thus had Moroni and Pahoran obtained the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note26a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>possession</span> of the city of Nephihah without the loss of one soul; and there were many of the Lamanites who were slain.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354956" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>Now it came to pass that many of the Lamanites that were prisoners were desirous to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note27a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>join</span> the people of Ammon and become a free people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354958" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>And it came to pass that as many as were desirous, unto them it was granted according to their desires.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354960" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>Therefore, all the prisoners of <span class="page-break" data-page="365"></span>the Lamanites did join the people of Ammon, and did begin to labor exceedingly, tilling the ground, raising all manner of grain, and flocks and herds of every kind; and thus were the Nephites relieved from a great burden; yea, insomuch that they were relieved from all the prisoners of the Lamanites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354962" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>Now it came to pass that Moroni, after he had obtained possession of the city of Nephihah, having taken many prisoners, which did reduce the armies of the Lamanites exceedingly, and having regained many of the Nephites who had been taken prisoners, which did strengthen the army of Moroni exceedingly; therefore Moroni went forth from the land of Nephihah to the land of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note30a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Lehi</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354964" id="p31"><span class="verse-number">31 </span>And it came to pass that when the Lamanites saw that Moroni was coming against them, they were again frightened and fled before the army of Moroni.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354966" id="p32"><span class="verse-number">32 </span>And it came to pass that <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note32a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Moroni</span> and his army did pursue them from city to city, until they were met by Lehi and Teancum; and the Lamanites fled from Lehi and Teancum, even down upon the borders by the seashore, until they came to the land of Moroni.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354968" id="p33"><span class="verse-number">33 </span>And the armies of the Lamanites were all gathered together, insomuch that they were all in one body in the land of Moroni. Now Ammoron, the king of the Lamanites, was also with them.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354970" id="p34"><span class="verse-number">34 </span>And it came to pass that Moroni and Lehi and Teancum did encamp with their armies round about in the borders of the land of Moroni, insomuch that the Lamanites were encircled about in the borders by the wilderness on the south, and in the borders by the wilderness on the east.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354971" id="p35"><span class="verse-number">35 </span>And thus they did encamp for the night. For behold, the Nephites and the Lamanites also were weary because of the greatness of the march; therefore they did not resolve upon any stratagem in the night-time, save it were Teancum; for he was exceedingly angry with Ammoron, insomuch that he considered that Ammoron, and Amalickiah his brother, had been the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note35a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>cause</span> of this great and lasting war between them and the Lamanites, which had been the cause of so much war and bloodshed, yea, and so much famine.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354972" id="p36"><span class="verse-number">36 </span>And it came to pass that Teancum in his anger did go forth into the camp of the Lamanites, and did let himself down over the walls of the city. And he went forth with a cord, from place to place, insomuch that he did find the king; and he did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note36a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>cast</span> a javelin at him, which did pierce him near the heart. But behold, the king did awaken his servants before he died, insomuch that they did pursue Teancum, and slew him.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354973" id="p37"><span class="verse-number">37 </span>Now it came to pass that when Lehi and Moroni knew that Teancum was dead they were exceedingly sorrowful; for behold, he had been a man who had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note37a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>fought</span> valiantly for his country, yea, a true friend to liberty; and he had suffered very many exceedingly sore afflictions. But behold, he was dead, and had gone the way of all the earth.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354974" id="p38"><span class="verse-number">38 </span>Now it came to pass that Moroni marched forth on the morrow, and came upon the Lamanites, insomuch that they did slay them with a great slaughter; and they did drive them out of the land; and they did flee, even that they did not return at that time against the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354975" id="p39"><span class="verse-number">39 </span>And thus ended the thirty and first year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi; and thus they had had wars, and bloodsheds, and famine, and affliction, for the space of many years.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354976" id="p40"><span class="verse-number">40 </span>And there had been murders, <span class="page-break" data-page="366"></span>and contentions, and dissensions, and all manner of iniquity among the people of Nephi; nevertheless for the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note40a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>righteous’</span> sake, yea, because of the prayers of the righteous, they were spared.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354977" id="p41"><span class="verse-number">41 </span>But behold, because of the exceedingly great length of the war between the Nephites and the Lamanites many had become hardened, because of the exceedingly great length of the war; and many were softened because of their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note41a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>afflictions</span>, insomuch that they did humble themselves before God, even in the depth of humility.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354978" id="p42"><span class="verse-number">42 </span>And it came to pass that after Moroni had fortified those parts of the land which were most exposed to the Lamanites, until they were sufficiently strong, he returned to the city of Zarahemla; and also Helaman returned to the place of his inheritance; and there was once more peace established among the people of Nephi.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354979" id="p43"><span class="verse-number">43 </span>And Moroni yielded up the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note43a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>command</span> of his armies into the hands of his son, whose name was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note43b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Moronihah</span>; and he retired to his own house that he might spend the remainder of his days in peace.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354980" id="p44"><span class="verse-number">44 </span>And Pahoran did return to his judgment-seat; and Helaman did take upon him again to preach unto the people the word of God; for because of so many wars and contentions it had become expedient that a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note44a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>regulation</span> should be made again in the church.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354981" id="p45"><span class="verse-number">45 </span>Therefore, Helaman and his brethren went forth, and did declare the word of God with much power unto the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note45a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>convincing</span> of many people of their wickedness, which did cause them to repent of their sins and to be baptized unto the Lord their God.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354982" id="p46"><span class="verse-number">46 </span>And it came to pass that they did establish again the church of God, throughout all the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354983" id="p47"><span class="verse-number">47 </span>Yea, and regulations were made concerning the law. And their <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note47a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>judges</span>, and their chief judges were chosen.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354984" id="p48"><span class="verse-number">48 </span>And the people of Nephi began to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note48a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>prosper</span> again in the land, and began to multiply and to wax exceedingly strong again in the land. And they began to grow exceedingly rich.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354985" id="p49"><span class="verse-number">49 </span>But notwithstanding their riches, or their strength, or their prosperity, they were not lifted up in the pride of their eyes; neither were they <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note49a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>slow</span> to remember the Lord their God; but they did humble themselves exceedingly before him.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354986" id="p50"><span class="verse-number">50 </span>Yea, they did remember how great things the Lord had done for them, that he had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note50a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>delivered</span> them from death, and from bonds, and from prisons, and from all manner of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note50b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>afflictions</span>, and he had <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note50c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>delivered</span> them out of the hands of their enemies.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354987" id="p51"><span class="verse-number">51 </span>And they did pray unto the Lord their God continually, insomuch that the Lord did bless them, according to his word, so that they did wax strong and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note51a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>prosper</span> in the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354988" id="p52"><span class="verse-number">52 </span>And it came to pass that all these things were done. And <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note52a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Helaman</span> died, in the thirty and fifth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Alma 63	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128354894" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/alma/63" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Alma 63</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128354095" id="title_number1">Chapter 63</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128354096" id="study_summary1">Shiblon and later Helaman take possession of the sacred records—Many Nephites travel to the land northward—Hagoth builds ships, which sail forth in the west sea—Moronihah defeats the Lamanites in battle. About 56–52 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="367"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354097" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And it came to pass in the commencement of the thirty and sixth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi, that <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Shiblon</span> took possession of those <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note1b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>sacred</span> things which had been delivered unto Helaman by Alma.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354098" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And he was a just man, and he did walk uprightly before God; and he did observe to do good continually, to keep the commandments of the Lord his God; and also did his brother.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354099" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>And it came to pass that <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Moroni</span> died also. And thus ended the thirty and sixth year of the reign of the judges.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354100" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>And it came to pass that in the thirty and seventh year of the reign of the judges, there was a large company of men, even to the amount of five thousand and four hundred men, with their wives and their children, departed out of the land of Zarahemla into the land which was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>northward</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354101" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>And it came to pass that Hagoth, he being an <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>exceedingly</span> curious man, therefore he went forth and built him an exceedingly large ship, on the borders of the land <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Bountiful</span>, by the land Desolation, and launched it forth into the west sea, by the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>narrow</span> neck which led into the land northward.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354102" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And behold, there were many of the Nephites who did enter therein and did sail forth with much provisions, and also many women and children; and they took their course northward. And thus ended the thirty and seventh year.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354103" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>And in the thirty and eighth year, this man built <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>other</span> ships. And the first ship did also return, and many more people did enter into it; and they also took much provisions, and set out again to the land northward.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354104" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And it came to pass that they were never heard of more. And we suppose that they were drowned in the depths of the sea. And it came to pass that one other ship also did sail forth; and whither she did go we know not.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354105" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>And it came to pass that in this year there were many people who went forth into the land <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>northward</span>. And thus ended the thirty and eighth year.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354106" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And it came to pass in the thirty and ninth year of the reign of the judges, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note10a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Shiblon</span> died also, and Corianton had gone forth to the land northward in a ship, to carry forth provisions unto the people who had gone forth into that land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354107" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>Therefore it became expedient for <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Shiblon</span> to confer those sacred things, before his death, upon the son of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>Helaman</span>, who was called <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11c"><sup class="marker">c</sup>Helaman</span>, being called after the name of his father.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354108" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>Now behold, all those <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>engravings</span> which were in the possession of Helaman were written and sent forth among the children of men throughout all the land, save it were those parts which had been commanded by Alma should <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>not go</span> forth.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354109" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>Nevertheless, these things were to be kept sacred, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>handed</span> down from one generation to another; therefore, in this year, they had been conferred upon Helaman, before the death of Shiblon.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354110" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And it came to pass also in this year that there were some dissenters <span class="page-break" data-page="368"></span>who had gone forth unto the Lamanites; and they were <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>stirred up</span> again to anger against the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354111" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And also in this same year they came down with a numerous army to war against the people of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Moronihah</span>, or against the army of Moronihah, in the which they were beaten and driven back again to their own lands, suffering great loss.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354112" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>And thus ended the thirty and ninth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128354113" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>And thus ended the account of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Alma</span>, and Helaman his son, and also Shiblon, who was his son.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Helaman 1	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128355902" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/hel/1" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Helaman 1</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<h1 data-aid="128355904" id="title1"><span class="dominant">The Book of Helaman</span></h1>^N			<p class="intro" data-aid="128355905" id="intro1">An account of the Nephites. Their wars and contentions, and their dissensions. And also the prophecies of many holy prophets, before the coming of Christ, according to the records of Helaman, who was the son of Helaman, and also according to the records of his sons, even down to the coming of Christ. And also many of the Lamanites are converted. An account of their conversion. An account of the righteousness of the Lamanites, and the wickedness and abominations of the Nephites, according to the record of Helaman and his sons, even down to the coming of Christ, which is called the book of Helaman, and so forth.</p>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128355906" id="title_number1">Chapter 1</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128355907" id="study_summary1">Pahoran the second becomes chief judge and is murdered by Kishkumen—Pacumeni fills the judgment seat—Coriantumr leads the Lamanite armies, takes Zarahemla, and slays Pacumeni—Moronihah defeats the Lamanites and retakes Zarahemla, and Coriantumr is slain. About 52–50 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355908" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And now behold, it came to pass in the commencement of the fortieth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi, there began to be a serious difficulty among the people of the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355909" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>For behold, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Pahoran</span> had died, and gone the way of all the earth; therefore there began to be a serious contention concerning who should have the judgment-seat among the brethren, who were the sons of Pahoran.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355910" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>Now these are their names who did contend for the judgment-seat, who did also cause the people to contend: Pahoran, Paanchi, and Pacumeni.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355911" id="p4"><span class="verse-number">4 </span>Now these are not all the sons of Pahoran (for he had many), but these are they who did contend for the judgment-seat; therefore, they did cause three <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note4a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>divisions</span> among the people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355912" id="p5"><span class="verse-number">5 </span>Nevertheless, it came to pass that Pahoran was appointed by the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note5a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>voice</span> of the people to be chief judge and a governor over the people of Nephi.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355913" id="p6"><span class="verse-number">6 </span>And it came to pass that Pacumeni, when he saw that he could not obtain the judgment-seat, he did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note6a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>unite</span> with the voice of the people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355914" id="p7"><span class="verse-number">7 </span>But behold, Paanchi, and that part of the people that were desirous that he should be their governor, was exceedingly wroth; therefore, <span class="page-break" data-page="369"></span>he was about to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note7a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>flatter</span> away those people to rise up in rebellion against their brethren.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355915" id="p8"><span class="verse-number">8 </span>And it came to pass as he was about to do this, behold, he was taken, and was tried according to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>voice</span> of the people, and condemned unto death; for he had raised up in rebellion and sought to destroy the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note8b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>liberty</span> of the people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355916" id="p9"><span class="verse-number">9 </span>Now when those people who were desirous that he should be their governor saw that he was condemned unto death, therefore they were angry, and behold, they sent forth one <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note9a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Kishkumen</span>, even to the judgment-seat of Pahoran, and murdered Pahoran as he sat upon the judgment-seat.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355917" id="p10"><span class="verse-number">10 </span>And he was pursued by the servants of Pahoran; but behold, so speedy was the flight of Kishkumen that no man could overtake him.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355918" id="p11"><span class="verse-number">11 </span>And he went unto those that sent him, and they all entered into a covenant, yea, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note11a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>swearing</span> by their everlasting Maker, that they would tell no man that Kishkumen had murdered Pahoran.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355919" id="p12"><span class="verse-number">12 </span>Therefore, Kishkumen was not known among the people of Nephi, for he was in disguise at the time that he murdered Pahoran. And Kishkumen and his band, who had covenanted with him, did mingle themselves among the people, in a manner that they all could not be found; but as many as were found were condemned unto <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note12a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>death</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355920" id="p13"><span class="verse-number">13 </span>And now behold, Pacumeni was appointed, according to the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note13a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>voice</span> of the people, to be a chief judge and a governor over the people, to reign in the stead of his brother Pahoran; and it was according to his right. And all this was done in the fortieth year of the reign of the judges; and it had an end.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355921" id="p14"><span class="verse-number">14 </span>And it came to pass in the forty and first year of the reign of the judges, that the Lamanites had gathered together an innumerable army of men, and <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note14a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>armed</span> them with swords, and with cimeters and with bows, and with arrows, and with head-plates, and with breastplates, and with all manner of shields of every kind.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355922" id="p15"><span class="verse-number">15 </span>And they came down again that they might pitch battle against the Nephites. And they were led by a man whose name was <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Coriantumr</span>; and he was a descendant of Zarahemla; and he was a <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note15b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>dissenter</span> from among the Nephites; and he was a large and a mighty man.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355923" id="p16"><span class="verse-number">16 </span>Therefore, the king of the Lamanites, whose name was Tubaloth, who was the son of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Ammoron</span>, supposing that Coriantumr, being a mighty man, could stand against the Nephites, with his strength and also with his great <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note16b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>wisdom</span>, insomuch that by sending him forth he should gain power over the Nephites—</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355924" id="p17"><span class="verse-number">17 </span>Therefore he did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note17a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>stir</span> them up to anger, and he did gather together his armies, and he did appoint Coriantumr to be their leader, and did cause that they should march down to the land of Zarahemla to battle against the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355926" id="p18"><span class="verse-number">18 </span>And it came to pass that because of so much contention and so much difficulty in the government, that they had not kept sufficient guards in the land of Zarahemla; for they had supposed that the Lamanites durst not come into the heart of their lands to attack that great city Zarahemla.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355928" id="p19"><span class="verse-number">19 </span>But it came to pass that Coriantumr did march forth at the head of his numerous host, and came upon the inhabitants of the city, and their march was with such exceedingly great speed that there <span class="page-break" data-page="370"></span>was no time for the Nephites to gather together their armies.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355929" id="p20"><span class="verse-number">20 </span>Therefore Coriantumr did cut down the watch by the entrance of the city, and did march forth with his whole army into the city, and they did slay every one who did oppose them, insomuch that they did take possession of the whole city.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355931" id="p21"><span class="verse-number">21 </span>And it came to pass that Pacumeni, who was the chief judge, did flee before Coriantumr, even to the walls of the city. And it came to pass that Coriantumr did smite him against the wall, insomuch that he died. And thus ended the days of Pacumeni.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355933" id="p22"><span class="verse-number">22 </span>And now when Coriantumr saw that he was in possession of the city of Zarahemla, and saw that the Nephites had fled before them, and were slain, and were taken, and were cast into prison, and that he had obtained the possession of the strongest hold in all the land, his heart <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note22a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>took courage</span> insomuch that he was about to go forth against all the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355934" id="p23"><span class="verse-number">23 </span>And now he did not tarry in the land of Zarahemla, but he did march forth with a large army, even towards the city of <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note23a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Bountiful</span>; for it was his determination to go forth and cut his way through with the sword, that he might obtain the north parts of the land.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355936" id="p24"><span class="verse-number">24 </span>And, supposing that their greatest strength was in the center of the land, therefore he did march forth, giving them no time to assemble themselves together save it were in small bodies; and in this manner they did fall upon them and cut them down to the earth.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355938" id="p25"><span class="verse-number">25 </span>But behold, this march of Coriantumr through the center of the land gave Moronihah great advantage over them, notwithstanding the greatness of the number of the Nephites who were slain.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355939" id="p26"><span class="verse-number">26 </span>For behold, Moronihah had supposed that the Lamanites durst not come into the center of the land, but that they would attack the cities round about in the borders as they had hitherto done; therefore Moronihah had caused that their strong armies should maintain those parts round about by the borders.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355941" id="p27"><span class="verse-number">27 </span>But behold, the Lamanites were not frightened according to his desire, but they had come into the center of the land, and had taken the capital city which was the city of Zarahemla, and were marching through the most capital parts of the land, slaying the people with a great slaughter, both men, women, and children, taking possession of many cities and of many strongholds.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355943" id="p28"><span class="verse-number">28 </span>But when Moronihah had discovered this, he immediately sent forth Lehi with an army round about to <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note28a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>head</span> them before they should come to the land Bountiful.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355944" id="p29"><span class="verse-number">29 </span>And thus he did; and he did head them before they came to the land Bountiful, and gave unto them battle, insomuch that they began to retreat back towards the land of Zarahemla.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355946" id="p30"><span class="verse-number">30 </span>And it came to pass that Moronihah did head them in their retreat, and did give unto them battle, insomuch that it became an exceedingly bloody battle; yea, many were slain, and among the number who were slain <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note30a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Coriantumr</span> was also found.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355948" id="p31"><span class="verse-number">31 </span>And now, behold, the Lamanites could not retreat either way, neither on the north, nor on the south, nor on the east, nor on the west, for they were surrounded on every hand by the Nephites.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355949" id="p32"><span class="verse-number">32 </span>And thus had Coriantumr plunged the Lamanites into the midst of the Nephites, insomuch that they were in the power of the Nephites, and he himself was slain, and the Lamanites did <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note32a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>yield</span> themselves into the hands of the Nephites.</p>^N			<span class="page-break" data-page="371"></span>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355951" id="p33"><span class="verse-number">33 </span>And it came to pass that Moronihah took possession of the city of Zarahemla again, and caused that the Lamanites who had been taken prisoners should depart out of the land in <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note33a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>peace</span>.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128355953" id="p34"><span class="verse-number">34 </span>And thus ended the forty and first year of the reign of the judges.</p>^N		</div>^N	</body>^N</html>
Helaman 2	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>^N<!DOCTYPE html>^N<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" data-aid="128356839" data-aid-version="4" data-content-type="chapter" data-uri="/scriptures/bofm/hel/2" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article" lang="eng" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lds.org/schema/lds/html5.xsd">^N	<head><meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />^N		<title>Helaman 2</title>^N		<meta charset="UTF-8" />^N	<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style_classic-scripture.css" /><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/images.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="../js/scripture-verse-number.js"></script><meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0" /></head>^N	<body>^N		<header>^N			<p class="title-number" data-aid="128356840" id="title_number1">Chapter 2</p>^N			<p class="study-summary" data-aid="128356841" id="study_summary1">Helaman, the son of Helaman, becomes chief judge—Gadianton leads the band of Kishkumen—Helaman’s servant slays Kishkumen, and the Gadianton band flees into the wilderness. About 50–49 <small>B.C.</small></p>^N		</header>^N		<div class="body-block">^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356842" id="p1"><span class="verse-number">1 </span>And it came to pass in the forty and second year of the reign of the judges, after Moronihah had established again peace between the Nephites and the Lamanites, behold there was no one to fill the judgment-seat; therefore there began to be a contention again among the people concerning who should fill the judgment-seat.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356843" id="p2"><span class="verse-number">2 </span>And it came to pass that <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Helaman</span>, who was the son of Helaman, was appointed to fill the judgment-seat, by the <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note2b"><sup class="marker">b</sup>voice</span> of the people.</p>^N			<p class="verse" data-aid="128356844" id="p3"><span class="verse-number">3 </span>But behold, <span class="study-note-ref" data-ref="note3a"><sup class="marker">a</sup>Kishkumen</span>, who had murdered Pahoran, did lay wait to destroy Helaman also;
